English name: Arine
Age: 10

Mother's full name and No.: Christine Martin 69
Parents living or dead: Living
State of child's health: Fair
Religion: Roman Catholic
Does applicant speak English? No
Previously attended school for — years

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

Feb. 21 1947

Mr. G.S. Bell,
Indian Agent,
Battleford, Sask.

Dear Sir:

Re: File 132-1-10 (Wtl)
Feb. 1st 1947

I just received yours of the 12th instant regarding the admission and discharge of the following:

No. 92 Alfred Byhette
No. 0232 Sarrazine Wolverine

I am glad to state that No. 92 was discharged on Sept. 1943 and was admitted again on the 15th of August under No. 150.

No. 0232 was discharged on Sept. 1945 and admitted again on August the 15th under No. 0310.

At Mr. Phelan's request, I gave them back their old number they previously had and as they had been admitted in the Sept. quarter, I did not put them on form 411 in the December quarter.

This will explain why Mr. Phelan is complaining about me not showing the admission and discharge of the above pupils on form 411 as I have a copy of same here in my files.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) F.X. Gagnon O.M.I.
Principal

Beauval Sask., Nov. 7 1947.

Mr. Philip Pielan,
Chief, Training Division,

Dear Sir—

File 132-1-3 (WT.F)

This is to acknowledge yours of the 30th ultimo regarding my quarterly return ending sept. 30.

I thank you very much for bringing up this matter to me and according to your instructions I have corrected my return and I hope this time it will be O.K.

As you will notice holidays are generally taken here on June the 15th to the 15th of August to accommodate the Indians from English River reserve who start early for their trapping grounds and also winds and cold weather that generally occur in early September when on my recruiting voyage.

In most cases however I was out of two days for few pupils as children left school on the 16th of June on account of the 15th being a sunday this year.

You will also notice that the boys have been entered right at the end of the girl's list. I could not do otherwise as I was short of forms. Next time, I will do better.

Yours very truly:

F.X. Gagnon O.M.I.
Principal.

Attention Mr. P. Phelan.
Re: School Children of White Fish Lake

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am in receipt of a letter from Reverend Father Ducharme, Missionary at La Loche Saskatchewan, in which he says that during the last week in August he chartered a plane to bring back to the Beauval School twelve Indian Children from White Fish Lake. None of these children were willing to return so his trip was a useless one. It appears that your sub-agent, at Ile à la Crosse, Mr. Tunstead notified Mr. Packman, agent at Meadow Lake about this matter. Mr. Packman answered that he could do nothing more than cancel the family allowance for the parents of these children.

It seems to me that if the above lack of interest in such a vital matter as school attendance, the agent should be reprimended and told that recruiting is one of his personal duties as Indian Agent.

If I am correctly informed Beauval has more than its authorized number of children and it does not matter very much whether these children from White Fish Lake are in attendance or not, but it is unfortunate that such a large group of children should remain without any education through the fault of an Agent of the Department.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
October 28, 1948.

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
University of Ottawa,
Laurier Avenue East,
Ottawa, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 28th instant with reference to children from Whitefish Lake Reserve whom you wish to recruit for the Beauval Residential School.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan

Father F.X. Gagnon, Principal of the above school is requesting permission to retain two of the pupils who are now sixteen for further training. These two are:

0290 Bella Smallboy of Big River Band, is sixteen but is a destitute child and he wishes to keep her in the school until she marries.

0316 Rosalie Monseult, Willow Band, is sixteen. She is the smartest girl that Father Gagnon has seen for some time, bright, trustworthy and always ready. /G.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Enclosed is a copy of a letter received from Indian Superintendent J.A. Davis of the Meadow Lake Agency in connection with two Indian girls at the Beauval Indian Residential School who have passed the age of sixteen but for whom authority is requested for continuing on the roll as grant-earning pupils.

With regard to pupil 0290, Bella Smallboy, the only reason for wishing to keep her at the school is that she is destitute and the Reverend Principal would like to keep her in the school until she marries. I do not recommend this as it is indefinite and whether she remains in the school till she is seventeen years of age or longer she will still be in the same position when discharged from the school.

With regard to pupil 0316, Rosalie Heneault, apparently this girl is unusually bright and might be considered for further education, I would therefore recommend that if her parents are willing she continue for at least another year on trial, with a view to continuing on through high school if her work in the next year appears to justify.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
AIR MAIL

July 21st, 1949.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of
Indian Agencies,
304 Post Office Bldg.,
Regina, Saskatchewan.

Re: Beauval Indian Residential School. Your File 1747-25-2-171

We are in receipt of your letter of the 14th instant regarding 2 Indian girls at the above school who have passed the age of 16.

With regard to Bella Smallboy, No. 0290, we are not exactly certain what you mean when you say she is destitute. Does this mean that she is an orphan and has no relatives with whom she can live, or does it mean that her parents are unable to support her? In order that there will be no misunderstanding on the part of all parties concerned, it is felt that the Principal should be requested to state definitely if in the event of the girl's remaining in the school, she will simply be used as an unpaid member of the staff, or if she will obtain either additional classroom education or a special training which would be of advantage to her. For this purpose I enclose a form which the Principal should complete and have returned to this office.

In view of the contents of the last paragraph of your letter, pupil No. 0316, Rosalie Heneault, may remain in the school for another year.

Bernard F. Neary,
PP/ST

With reference to Department letter of June 9th, in connection with Mr. M. Schieff of Brochet, Manitoba, transporting Indian school pupils in an unlicensed aircraft.

In telephone conversation with Mr. Jones of Prince Albert, he informed me that this offence occurred in connection with the Reverend Father recruiting and transporting Indian pupils to the school at the commencement of the term.

It is quite possible that Mr. Schieff's aircraft was used by more than one school Principal. I do not think there will be any reoccurrence, as I have issued instructions to all Indian Superintendents that they will impress it upon the Reverend Father, in charge of the schools, that Indian pupils must not be conveyed in any aircraft unless both the plane and the pilot are licensed by the Air Transport Board.

April 6, 1950

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Resources and Development,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Information has been received that E. Schieff of Brochet, Manitoba, on Reindeer Lake, has transported school children from Brochet to the Indian School.

Schieff is not licensed by the Board to operate any form of commercial air service. The R.C.M.P. have been requested to investigate his alleged illegal operations.

In view of the information received, the Board directed that this matter be brought to the attention of your Branch as you will, no doubt, wish to issue instructions to your Field Officers to refrain from requesting air transportation from air carriers other than those licensed by the Board.

Would you please investigate the alleged illegal transportation of school children by Schieff on behalf of your Department and inform the Board of the result of your investigation.

Your co-operation in this respect will be very much appreciated.

Yours truly,

Gerald Morisset,
Secretary.

Stony Rapids, Sask.,

Mr. E. Law,
Superintendent,
The Pas Indian Agency,
THE PAS, Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

Re: John Baptiste Dentouzie

Herewith please find Saskatchewan Government Airways invoice A.4803 for the sum of $59.10 this being air transportation charges on the above mentioned treaty member.

Kindly be advised that this lad does not belong to this agency, although he has been in this vicinity for the past five summers living with whom ever would take him in and being very much a destitute problem to one and all. I had this young lad out to the Beauval School last winter up to the end of the school term and owing to poor direction of this lad from Beauval School he was brought back to here in error when he was slated to go to either Brochet or to Sturgeon Landing where he was to attend school on the commencement of the fall term of this year. And so it is that he is still here and being very much of a problem to this agency.

In a very recent letter from Reverend Father F.X. Gagnon Principal, Beauval School, Beauval, Sask., he has stated that this boy has a step-father living near Brochet and that the step-father wishes to have the boy, but the means of getting him to Brochet is a problem, unless we try to obtain authority from the Superintendent of Education, Indian Affairs Branch to have him flown out to Brochet. This is the only means, as I had to go through this procedure to get him into Beauval.

.......2
It would be very much appreciated if you would kindly advise any suggestions you may have and to get this boy back to his step-father and back to the band that he belongs to, there is no information here as to what band he belonged to or even band number, also no record of parents other than that of the step-father.

Yours truly,

L.D. Ward,
Asst. Indian Agent.

Enclosure.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Attention: Colonel B.F. Neary

Enclosed herewith is this Agency's voucher #135 of today's date in favour of Saskatchewan Government Airways which covers fare for John Baptiste Dantouze #1 Barren Lands Band.

I also enclose copy of letter received from Mr. L.D. Ward, Assistant Indian Agency, of Athabaska Indian Agency, in connection with the lad who was flown from Isle la Crosse to Stony Rapids. I was never informed of this flight and never knew that same had taken place until I received invoice and Mr. Ward's letter of November 29, 1950. You will note that this boy is at present at Stony Rapids, still not having reached his destination which was Brochet. As he is 16 years of age he would not be returning to residential school, and I would be obliged if you would inform me as to steps to be taken in regard to transportation from Stony Rapids to Brochet.

As stated earlier, I had no knowledge of flight which has taken place but trust that voucher can be honoured as submitted.

E. Law,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.

MEADOW LAKE, Sask.,
September 25, 1952.

Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Reference your telegram of September 28, 1952 regarding the admission of children from the Meadow Lake and Waterhen Lake Reserves to the Beauval Indian Residential School, I wish to state that I advised Father Landry that he could take children from the Waterhen Lake Reserve this year but not from the Meadow Lake Reserve, further that in view of the erection of a day school at Waterhen Lake Reserve that he would not be able to admit children from that Reserve next year after the school opens.

I issued these instructions to the Principal on the basis of a letter written to him by Mr. J.A. Davis, formerly Superintendent of this Agency, copies of which were forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, and Mr. Ostrander, Regional Supervisor, Regina. This letter was written on August 12, 1952, File #951-171/25-1, and as no comments had been received in this office on the statements made in the letter I assumed that this summed up the Department's policy on this matter.

However, in view of your telegram, I have written to the Principal and advised him of the policy which you have now laid down that children attending residential schools will be allowed to continue there until they have completed grade 8. Am I correct in assuming that children who have not previously attended a residential school will not be permitted to attend after a day school opens on their home Reserve?

S.K. Walker,
Clerk in Charge.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education,
Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I wish to express my sincere gratitude for the readiness with which you have solved the problem concerning the enrolment of children from Meadow Lake and Water Hen reserves.

Enclosed herewith kindly find a copy of my letter of recent date to Mr. Walker, clerk in charge at the Meadow Lake Office. This latter explains why I have been induced to exceed the quota of children, authorized by your Department for the Beauval School.

May I point out to you, dear Sir, that in the case of Meadow Lake children, I have followed as near as possible the terms of your telegram: "all children previously in attendance" here. If I have been induced to admit five new-comers from the Meadow Lake reserve, it is only after entreaties from the part of the parents or guardians and for some good reasons, as most of these five children are orphans or assimilable to orphans, whose homes are too far from the Day school or whose home conditions are unfavorable and unsatisfactory.

I trust, dear Mr. Phelan, that these explanations will meet your approval and beg you to accept once more the best regards of the whole Staff of Beauval Indian School.

Yours very gratefully & sincerely,

M. Landry, O.M.I., Principal.
October 13, 1952,

Mr. S. L. Walker,
Clerk in charge,
Meadow Lake Indian Office,
Meadow Lake, Sask.

Dear Sir:

Due to the fact that I am a probationer in the charge of Principalship, it has been quite difficult for me to foresee what enrolment the School would have for this term. As it is, we now have one hundred and thirty-eight pupils registered; but in spite of the fact that we have exceeded the quota authorized previously, I feel that sanitary conditions are satisfactory since we have provided extra sleeping quarters for both boys and girls. In case we have the benefit of a visit from Mr. Conrad or any other Government Official in the near future I presume that this will meet their approval as it did that of Mr. Gervais, this last week.

I wish to make clear to you, however, that amongst the registered pupils there are at least eight below school-age who were admitted for special reasons; for instance, two little Mioulteho girls aged 4½ and 3 years who were accepted because of their mother's death. Mr. J.F. Ostrander authorized me to do this when I had the pleasure of meeting him at Meadow Lake in the first days of this month.

At the time of my interview with Mr. Ostrander there were hardly more than a hundred pupils enrolled for the term, hence room for about twenty more. Therefore, on receiving Mr. Phelan's telegram, I left for Meadow Lake to gather the children who had been at School here before. At least this was my intention! Once there, however, I found it difficult to resist the plea of certain parents or guardians, like those of Bruno Baer and Lester, both orphans, and Victor Matche whose home is so far from school. Thus, instead of having twenty some pupils on returning, I had twenty four, and then also, a few more arrived from the Northern reserves.

I hope my procedure did not appear to have been dictated by a spirit of competition against the Meadow Lake agency. This was not at all my motives. Although it is true that the school here was built for the benefit of the children of the Northern regions, we must admit that there will always be exceptions for pupils of Meadow Lake and Water Hen reserves, whose homes are too far from the Day school or whose home conditions are unfavorable, as it is so clearly explained by Mr. Phelan.

I trust, dear Mr. Walker, that your zeal for the good of the Indian children will help you to understand my point of view and that our efforts for this good cause may be always blessed with a whole-hearted co-operation on our part and yours.

I remain,

Yours very truly,

M. Landry, O.M.I., Principal

Dear Sir:

The Department has received the memoranda of inquiry following the deaths of the pupils of the Beauval Indian Residential School during the month of March last. Perhaps my first duty is to offer the sympathy of the Department to the Principal and Staff of the School whose sad lot it was to witness the deaths of so many of their charges.

It is always wise, however, to try to profit by experience, and the Department would like to be sure that nothing is left undone, particularly by itself, to provide in advance for an outbreak of this kind.

Dear Sirs:

In accordance with the inquiry received from the Department of Indian Affairs, the undersigned have the following report to make of the epidemic which occurred at the Indian Residential School at Beauval, Sask., during the months of February and March last, and which resulted in the serious illness of almost all of the pupils, and the subsequent death of fourteen.

There is good accommodation at the school for occasional sickness among the children, and supplies of medicine were sufficient for their care in the emergency. The epidemic started with influenza about February 10th; it was general among the children, but not serious. They were rapidly recovering from this sickness (at that time it was general all over Canada in a fairly severe form) when a few cases of measles appeared among them, and rapidly spread until all were infected. Influenza in some of the children had developed into pneumonia. Many had weakened constitutions due to the prevalence among the Indians of tubercular diseases, sore throats, and diseases of the eyes, teeth and skin. The medical authorities noted that most deaths occurred among persons weakened by such ailments, which are agreed to have a debilitating effect upon the system.

Four different sick-rooms were in use, for children in various stages of sickness. A supplementary staff was used in the school to do routine work, leaving the Sisters free to act as nurses. Doctor Lavoie was called five times, and his instructions carefully followed. A trained nurse was in charge of the sickrooms, and a staff of fourteen persons gave all their time to the care of the sick. Mr. Macdonald, of the Battleford district of the Department, was in continual touch with the situation, and gave his full approval and close attention to all measures taken. Under Dr. Lavoie's direction, and supervised by the principal of the school, everything possible was done for the children.

There is no way of knowing just how the epidemic started. It is possible that it was communicated through, or its virulence increased by, the presence of people from the village at religious services at the Mission church. There is no church in the village, and the presence of these people at services must carry a continual danger of infection to the children, when an epidemic is prevalent. They will build a church this summer, with the co-operation of the principal of the school.
The Indians have many congenital weaknesses: tuberculosis, throat diseases, bad teeth, eye troubles, and others. They generally are quickly infected by, and often succumb to, whatever infectious diseases they contract, because of weakened constitutions. It would seem that it is necessary to increase the health of the natives generally, as well as of the school children. Although the Department is not obligated to do so, no doubt if there were greater co-operation with the doctor at Isle à la Crosse, and if more medicines and equipment were placed at his disposal, much could be done in this direction. It would be advisable to send a specialist to the school every autumn to prescribe for diseases of the eyes, nose, throat, teeth and skin among the children. As for tuberculosis, the Department has taken care of this, and at the school the medicines supplied by the Department are given to the children, particularly those intended to build up their resistance; and a general good health regimen is insisted upon.

From this general description of the epidemic of influenza, pneumonia and measles, and suggestions as to the prevention of future ones, it is evident that everything possible was done for the sick, and that their inherent physical condition made them easy victims of these three serious diseases which successively afflicted them.

Signed

Principal of Beauval School

Indian Agent, Battleford

Health Officer, Isle & La Crosse

Sir,

Per Department letter No. 132-1-23, May 10th re epidemic and serious loss of children at the Beauval School, with request that this be taken up during my visit up there, I beg to report as follows:

While North, I had both Rev. Father Bleau and Dr. Lavoie on the whole circuit with me, and the matter of health and care of children was taken up and discussed there from all angles. I am attaching in duplicate a report on this, written by the Rev. Father Bleau, explaining the action taken during the epidemic and precautions for the future, which has been signed by all three of us. I believe this pretty well covers the situation.

It will be noted that the general impression is that some of the contagion was contracted through outsiders at Church services, so that arrangements are now being made to have a separate Church, and people from the settlement across the river will not again be in direct contact with the children of the school. However, as the epidemic was apparently general, and would most probably have hit the school in any case, it is hard to say whether the contacts in church are actually to blame. In any case, the necessary precautions are being taken.

It will also be noted that a request is made for a dental and Eye, Ear, Nose and Throat clinic, and I can assure the Department that this is very necessary as there are several bright and otherwise healthy children who are in serious need of eye attention. If it is not possible to send in a clinic after reopening of school some of these children should be brought out for attention as there are at least two girls that are in danger now of losing their eyesight for need of this attention.

In conclusion, I might say that the care of the children at the Beauval School is exceptionally good, and any loss or sickness is most certainly not through the neglect or carelessness of any of the staff.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

H. W. McGill, Esq.,
Director of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Statement of Rev. Father F.X. Gagnon re: death of Hermas (Jacquot) Piche.

On the second of July, at about eleven o'clock A.M., I François Xavier Gagnon, C.M.I., principal of the Indian Residential School at Beauval, Sask., driving the school truck on my way back from the Beauval village, had with me in the cab two kids and Mr. B.G. Brown riding in the box with a couple kids.

After I had passed the gate at the school yard, coming up the hill, I saw Jacquot Piche running down towards the right side of the truck. At the time I was driving on low, at about 8 miles per hour. When I passed him, he was about 25 feet from the truck and then lost sight of him; the road turning to the left about 45 degrees. I then changed gear on the top of the hill, slowed down a little bit and then picked up a little speed, about ten miles per hour. As the boy was coming towards the right side of the truck, at the speed I was going, I thought he was trying to follow or run after the truck behind. So I did not pay any more attention to him.

At the same time, the older kid in the cab said in Cree to Jacquot: "Come on and step on the running board of the truck." I answered right away: "Don't do that." Almost instantly the truck passed through a little hole and jumped up a little, and almost immediately, I felt like the right hand wheel of the truck had passed over a stone. As I know there was no stone there, I stop right away, jumped off the truck and ran at the back to see what it was. Then I saw the boy just getting up, lifting up his arms towards me. Right away, I had the impression that he had passed under the wheel and while getting up I could not prevent telling him: "Keep away from the truck while running," and at the same time I took him in my arms to the infirmary at the school. On my way, I could hear rattles in his throat or lungs. In the infirmary, I laid him down on a bed, put a wet towel on his head and ran for the nurse. As soon as I found her, we rush back to the infirmary. Then, the nurse helped by the other Sisters untied his shirt, took the pulse, put ice on his head and turning towards me she said: "I am afraid, he is going to pass away." Then I ran for my prayer book and when I came back a few minutes later I just had the time to anoint him and he breathed his last breath. Before he died he vomited a little blood.

After that, I immediately notified the Coroner, Dr. Lavoie and the Police and sent a wire to the Indian Agent at Battleford.

The boys of the school very seldom run after the truck and on many occasions, I told them to keep away from the truck while in motion, as I was always afraid that one of them would get hurt.

Jacquot Piche, his brother Jean and his sister Marguerite have been in school three years. Their father was drowned about 4 years ago. They are living at Tchepwayan Prairie. They are Tchepwayans.

This statement is true to the best of my knowledge.

Signed: F.X. Gagnon C.M.I.

Statement of Bertrand G. Brown.

I Bertrand Gavin Brown of Beauval states as follows:

On July the second about 10.50 a.m., I went with Father Gagnon of the Beauval Indian Residential School from the Beauval Village in the school truck to the Indian School situated about two miles north of the Village. Father Gagnon was driving the truck. He had two children with him in the cab.

I was riding in the box, standing at the front, leaning on the top of the cab. As the truck came through the school gate and started up the small hill close to the school yard, I noticed one of the boys belonging to the school come running down towards the right side of the truck. I thought he was going to try to step on the running board of the truck, but he drew back as he got closer to the truck. In doing so the front part of the truck went past the point where the boy was standing. I was standing in the front of the box looking towards the front. I did not see him after that and I thought that the truck had passed him by. At that moment the truck suddenly stopped, and I turned around and saw the little boy standing at the rear end of the truck. He looked as if he had been hit by the truck as it went by. I saw Father Gagnon get out of the cab immediately and rush to the boy, and the little boy stopped towards Father Gagnon and the father held him close. Then the boy collapsed and Father carried him to the school.

I have often driven with Father Gagnon in the truck and I have always found him a careful driver. I have never noticed the children at the school running after the truck, so due to this reason I did not expect the deceased boy to try to get on. At the time of the accident the truck was travelling about ten miles per hour.

This statement is true to the best of my knowledge.

Signed: B.G. Brown.

Certified a true copy.

Statement of Rev. Sister Tucker.

I Sister Francis Catherine Tucker states as follows:
I am in charge of the dairy at the Indian School at Beauval. About 10:30 a.m. on July the second I was upstairs in a room of the second floor. I was alone. I saw the Mission truck coming the yard towards the priests house. It was about half way from the gate to the Fathers' house. I saw a man standing in the front of the box, and two little boys who from my position looked also to be in the box towards the rear end. Both seemed to be on the left side of the box about half way. I saw one of the boys lying on the ground just behind the truck. I could see the right side of the truck only. The truck stopped a very short distance ahead and the other boy jumped down, and he ran towards his companion who was still lying on the ground. I saw Father Gagnon going towards the boy. As the Father was close to him, the boy seemed to stand on his feet, and I saw the Father gather him in his arms, and he carried him to the school. Not thinking that the accident was serious, I continued my work. Shortly afterward Sister St. Adelin came and told me that the boy was dead. It was not until the boy had died that I knew who he was. This happened about 200 yards from the school. At the time of the accident the truck was driving quite slow. I did not know who was driving at the time; I saw often Father Gagnon driving and he is very careful about the safety of the people who are around. I know that he always make sure that none of the kids are around when he drives or back up, and tells them to keep away.

This is a true statement to the best of my knowledge.

Signed: Sister Francis A.C. Tucker.

Certified a true copy.

Statement of Marie Rose Couillonneur.

I Marie Rose Couillonneur states as follows:
I work in the kitchen of the Beauval Indian School. About ten o'clock July the second I went up to the sewing room on the second floor. I heard the truck coming. Statement of Jean Piche.

Jean Piche aged 10 years states as follows:

About ten o'clock the second of July I was in the school yard with my brother Hermas. I saw the truck coming the hill towards the school yard. My brother ran after the truck on the right side, and I kept on walking. I saw Hermas catching the right side of the box and run alongside hanging on with his left hand. He was trying to climb to the box, and all of a sudden he fell down. As he fell down, the side of the box hit the right side of his head. I did not notice the truck go over him. Immediately this happened the truck stopped. Father Gagnon took him in his arms. Father Gagnon was driving the truck. Father lifted Hermas and took him to the school. The Father always told us kids to keep away from the truck when in motion, and due to this reason I never saw any kids running after the truck in the yard. My brother and I have been three years in the school. When Hermas grabbed the truck I was quite close to him; when he fell I was about 40 feet behind the truck. From where I stood, I could see what happened quite clearly.

This statement is true to the best of my knowledge.

At the completion of the investigation Dr. Lavioe Cerney advised that due to the circumstances of the case that he did not consider an Inquest necessary, and he therefore released the body for burial.

The statements of Jean Piche and Victor Desjarlais who were quite close to the deceased at the time of the accident seem to indicate quite clearly what had happened and their story also corroborate the injuries noted on the deceased body. In view of this the Cerney and the writer came to the conclusion that the accident occurred as follows; The boy having caught up to the truck in all probabilities he intended to climb on the step beside the cab as the intake gasoline pipe for the gas tank is located beside this step. It would be the only suitable thing for him to hang on to. This pipe extends about four inches above the tank and is located on the right side of the truck between the cab and the box as the truck began to gain speed at the top of the grade, the boy lost his balance or else the truck began to travel too fast for him and the result that the corner of the box hit him on the left side of the neck causing him to spin around so that his right side would be nearer the box. In doing so the box caught him again on the right temple and probably as he fell down outside tire on the dual wheels at the rear could easily have come in contact with his groin.

The scene of the accident was carefully examined but nothing could be learned which might assist in the investigation. The truck was also checked its a two ton Chevrolet 1942 Model, Box. License No. 72693. It has a large box 12 ft. 7 inches long seven feet wide and forty five inches high, the box extends Cent'd. Page 6.
The box measures twelve and one half inches from the end on both sides, and it measures five inches back from the end. It has dual wheels on the rear extending about five inches out from the box. The truck is equipped with a grid rear view mirror; the brakes were tested by the writer and they are in first-class condition. Father GAGNON stated that he had been driving off and on for the last ten years, and that he had driven this truck continually since it was purchased in 1941. He was in receipt of a Saskatchewan Driver's License No. 113627 for the year 1942-43.

The writer was advised by Father GAGNON that the death of the child mentioned would also be investigated by a board of three men appointed under the direction of the Indian Agent at the completion of which the Agent will comply with the provisions of the Vital Statistics Act.

In the F.M. of this date the writer in company with S/Cst. Johnson per cutboard meter Code #7374 returned to No. 2 La Crosse upon arriving at the Detachment the following telegram was received from the C.O., Prince Albert Sub-Division:

I immediately sent the following telegram to the C.O., Prince Albert Sub-Division:

Herma PICHÉ eight years old Indian child killed at Beaupré accidentally by a truck operated by Father GAGNON ten o'clock date investigation completed by Dr. Layce and writer step Dr. Layce Coroner advised no Inquest necessary report following.

In view of the facts surrounding this case and the Coroner's decision no further action will be taken by this office unless otherwise instructed and the file will therefore be considered closed.

TRUCK HAD PASSED over a stone, as I knew that there was no stone there. I stopped right away, jumped off the truck and ran at the back to see what it was. Then I saw the boy just getting up, lifting up his arms towards me. Right away I had the impression that he had passed under the wheel, and while getting up I could not prevent from telling him "Keep away from the truck while running", and at the same time I took him in my arms to the Infirmary at the school, on my way I could hear rattles in his throat and lungs. In the Infirmary I laid him down on a bed, put a wet towel on his head and ran for the nurse. As soon as I found her, we rushed back to the Infirmary, then the nurse helped by the other Sisters untied his shirt, took his pulse, put ice on his head, and turning towards me she said, "I am afraid he is going to pass away". Then I ran for my prayer book and when I came back a few minutes later, I just had time to anoint him and he breathed his last breath. Just before he died he vomited a little blood. After that I immediately notified the Coroner Dr. LAVOIE and the Police and sent a wire to the Indian Agent at Battleford.

4. The boys of the school very seldom run after the truck and on many occasion, I told them to keep away from the truck while in motion, as I was always afraid that one of them would get hurt.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 132-1-23 of the 27th ultimo regarding the unsatisfactory registration of Vital Statistics at Ile à la Crosse.

Some time before your letter reached this office I received a Police Report on this and immediately telephoned the Registrar General here, and as I was going through Battleford I advised him I would talk over the matter with Agent Ostrander, which I did. Upon my return I again got in touch with the Registrar General's office and arranged for a meeting with him today. I have just returned from that meeting.

Upon investigation of this case I found that in 1936 Mr. MacDonald, then Agent, wrote to the Registrar General's office suggesting that five different Priests in the North country be appointed as registrars for Treaty No. 10, and since that time this has been carried out in a haphazard way. In fact this method has been found very unsatisfactory and my recommendation to the Registrar General was that the registration for Treaty No. 10 be left entirely in the hands of the Indian Agent, and Mr. Ostrander has agreed to this, that is when he pays Treaty he will attend to the registration of the different bands in that part of his agency. In my opinion this is the only way that it can be done satisfactorily, and I am now writing to Agent Ostrander to bring it about.

Regarding the registration of Hermas Piche, the Treaty Indian Juvenile who was killed in a truck accident last Summer at Beauval, I am instructing Agent Ostrander to register him accordingly.

While I was at the Registrar General's office I learned that some of our Agents are sending in the certificates registering births and deaths in a very sloppy manner, and if they only knew it there is no use sending these in to the Registrar General unless they are completed. In very many cases I was told they are not completed and it is necessary to write two or three times in order to get the required information. I shall endeavour to see that these reports are filled out properly and the Registrar........

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of François Denevouzare, Pupil No. 116, of the Indian Residential School at Batoche, Saskatchewan, (place) on May 3, 1943.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

To the Commissioner
of Indian Affairs.
Winnipeg.

Sir,

I beg humbly to expose to the consideration of the Indian Department that, owing to the very limited number of Roman Catholic Schools for Indian children and to the great distance of a considerable number of Indian Reserves from any of those schools, we certainly have not the necessary accommodation to receive all the Indian children who could and ought to be sent to our schools.

I think I am not out of the truth in saying that in some districts we have not at all, in that regard, the same advantages enjoyed by other Denominations. For instance if we take the regions of Fort Pelly, Crooked Lake, Moose Mountain, Fort Ellice &c where there are a large number of Indians among whom a considerable number of R.Catholics and a great number of Pagans, you will remark that whilst the Protestants have six schools supported by the Government, viz:

1 Industrial School, 3 Boarding Schools, and 2 Day Schools, there is only one Day School held by the Catholics at Fort Pelly; this making the very considerable difference that whilst the Protestants have
have schools at proximity of all Indian Reserves, we have many of the same Reserves which are very distant from any of the R.C. Schools.

For any one, who knows how the Indians hate to send their children far away, it will appear evident that our condition for recruiting school children is far inferior to the condition of other denominations, and that we have not really the necessary accommodations to receive all the children of catholic or pagan belief whom their parents would like to sent to R.C. Schools, but whom they refuse to send to Qu'Appelle Industrial School on account of the great distance; this being particularly the case when those children are young.

This deficiency in the number of our schools will be felt worse in the future, as I hear that the intention of the Department is to admit at the Industrial Schools only the children who will have attained the age of 14 years, and to have the younger children sent to boarding or day schools.

If the Department takes into consideration that in the whole District of Assiniboia and in all the regions of Manitoba West of Portage la Prairie, we have only three schools supported by the Government, viz: one Industrial School at Qu'Appelle, one Boarding School at Touchwood.
Touchwood Hills, and one day school at Fort Pelly, whilst the Protestants have not less than ten schools also supported by the Government, viz: three Industrial Schools at Brandon, Elkhorn and Regina, five Boarding Schools at Birtle, Crooked Lake, Fort Pelly, Pile Hills and Touchwood Hills, and two day schools at Pelly and Sioux Reserve; we will not be found too exacting and asking for more than our share of the Government help in asking to have the number of Roman Catholic Schools augmented.

I beg therefore hereby to make application for the establishment of a Boarding School for the education of Indian children at the R.C.Mission at Crooked Lake where there is a large number of Indians, and where we have now two residing Missionaries. And I ask you to be kind enough to recommend my request to the favourable consideration of the Department of Indian Affairs, and to see that the funds required for the erection of a school building as well as for the tuition and boarding of twenty children are included in the estimates to be submitted to the Indian Department.

I have the honour &c.

J.P. Magnan.
P. O.M.I.

Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that the Rev. Father Campau has requested me to write you in support of his application, which I understand he has made direct to you, for the establishment of a Roman Catholic Boarding School on Cowessess Reserve to be built in the valley near to the end of Crooked Lake.

I must state that I am greatly in favour of good boarding schools on the Reserves for the following reasons,- That they are able to take younger children, that they are more homelike, that a closer and more family like supervision can be kept over the smaller number of pupils kept; that the parents prefer the Schools on the Reserves to those at a distance and that they will make good feeders to the Industrial Schools to which the older pupils might be transferred to finish off their training.

I shall be pleased, if the necessary funds can be provided, to see this School established as there are a lot of young children which the parents would probably

The Indian Commissioner,

more willingly send to this School being near to their homes, and also that it may prove of use in persuading "She Sheeps" party to allow their children to attend it, being at the other end of the Lake from their Reserve and almost within sight.

The Secretary:

Re application for grant to cover cost of modern improvements placed in Cowesses boarding school.

This school has been put up by the Roman Catholics at a cost of over $15,000 and was opened two years ago. The Department has contributed nothing towards the building but in November '99 at the urgent request of the Premier the Deputy Minister authorized the payment of the usual per capita grant on a basis of twenty pupils for this school from the 1st July of that year. This grant has now been increased to provide for forty. In March 1900 Mr Miller of Moosomin wrote to Mr Douglas M.P. stating that the Presbyterian body was dissatisfied with the action of the Government in agreeing to pay a grant to the Roman Catholic church for the building of a mission at the Round Lake reserve. This letter was not made official and is not on file but I have before me a memorandum I prepared on the 19th March of that year in reference to this protest, which is on file 117080 and turned out here-with. This protest refers to the building of a Roman Catholic mission at Round Lake and not to the establishment of a school at Crooked Lake on Cowesses Reserve, both these places being in the Crooked Lakes Agency.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6303, file 651-1, part 1)
The Roman Catholic school was in operation and recognized by the Department before this protest was received and the religious profession of the Indians in the Crooked Lakes Agency would show that their claims to have a boarding school are even greater than those of the Presbyterians.

The Presbyterian boarding school at Round Lake has been established since 1884 and has received the per capita allowance since 1887.

A grant for forty pupils is now provided for each of these schools and judging from Mr Inspector McGibbon's report there is ample field for both of them without clash of interests.

The Presbyterians claim to have spent $7000 on their school building without any assistance from the Government and if the Roman Catholics receive compensation for their outlay, it is most likely that they will feel dissatisfied and make a similar claim.

To the honorable J. D. McLean, Secretary of Indian Department.

Honorable Sir:

I beg to be authorized to state special demand to your Department in favor of our school.

There is now in construction a rural telephone line which shall come within three miles of our school. Unfortunately, on that distance there is no farmer who could help building the line closer to us. Now the Indian Department is aware that our school is at a distance of eleven miles from the nearest railway station. A telephone line would be a great help to get in touch with the rest of the world and would render to us as well as to the Indians of the Reserve generally, many important services. This school is at the same time the Post Office of the Indians, and it would help them in many ways. Many a time would this school or the people around be in trouble and expenses, if they could have information in time, specially from the railway station.

The cost of this line would be $500.00.

I humbly would ask you, honorable Sir, if you would help us in getting this line to the school. We would have to pass it, if built in a straight line, through a small part of the reserve, but only through land unsuitable for cultivation.
Confident in your earnestness to work for the prosperity of the Indians, I remain

very respectfully yours,

Marieval Sask.

Dear Mr Scott:

The Oblate Missionaries of Manitoba and Southern Saskatchewan, through their Provincial Administration, wish to offer to the Department, the last of the four schools the latter intends to purchase. That school is called COWESSES INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL and is situated at MARIEVAL (via Grayson) Sask., in a magnificent locality.

The first draft of our proposals concerning that school was as follows:

School building (basement, 3 stories, brick veneer, 100 x 37, new)........$45,000.00
Barn, fully modern, 60 x 32..................5,000.00
Granary, boiler room, shop...................1,500.00
Principal's house.............................2,000.00
Farm Implements..............................3,000.00
Live stock, cattle and horses...............3,000.00
Land (160 acres).............................3,000.00

Total: $62,500.00

It is our desire to keep close as close as possible to the above figures but we wish to note the following:

1o-We believe that a sufficient quantity of land must be assured for farming purposes as it was the case with the Muscowequan and Pine Creek schools. We had mentioned 160 acres in our offer but we beg to change the latter as follows: the least that should be taken over by the Department are two parcels of land, one of 206 acres, including the site of the school and outbuildings, and ano-

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

With reference to the formal offer of the Cowessess Indian Residential School property made in Father Guy's letter of December 15th, last, I wish to make the following observations. In connection with these 3 of his letter, under the heading "Actual value of the property" (church authorities' valuation) I wish to point out that under "lands", 206 acres was purchased in 1908 from the Indian reserve at $15 per acre. The 282.7 acre parcel was secured evidently in the open market. This parcel is across the Qu'Appelle river, approximately a mile from the school.

As far as buildings are concerned, the main building was completed in 1917. The Department provided a total of $1344 capital expense (fiscal years 1907-10). With reference to chattels, (page 3, Father Guy's letter and Exhibit F.) farm implements $4,890 appears satisfactory. Under Shop Equipment, whiffletrees, irons, clevises, chains, oils, bolts, screws, nails, iron, solder, etc., belting and stove pipes, a total of $292 should be subtracted from $1561, leaving $1269. The live stock inventory is satisfactory; but from the dairy, laundry and bakery shops should be deducted the refrigerator, which was built by the Department; flour, soap and lye, leather, tacks and thread, a total of $1680, leaving a balance of $591. In connection with furniture, the desks, clocks, 12 sewing machines and kitchen outfit were supplied by the Department, and the trunks could not be allowed - a total deduction of $805, leaving $2967.70. The whole clothing item of $9442.70 should be struck out, as also should the chapel equipment of $924.

I note that the bake oven, $266.14, and laundry machinery, $816, supplied by the Department, 1924-25, are not included in the inventory.

June 13th, 1925

Dr. Scott -

With reference to your memo of the 4th instant relative to the purchase by the Department of the Cowessess Indian Residential School in Saskatchewan,

The Minister instructs that Mr. Otis Holden of Indian Head, Sask. may be given the commission to appraise this property.

W.J.F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.
Ottawa, June 17, 1925.

Dear Mr. Holden:

This Department is considering the purchase of the Cowessess Indian Residential School, at Mariewal, north of Broadview. The property is owned by the Oblate Fathers of the Roman Catholic Church, with whom we have been negotiating. It is our intention to purchase 206 acres in Sections 5 and 8, T. 19 A., R. 5, W. 2nd, on which the school buildings are situated; 282 acres in Sections 3 and 4, T. 19, R. 5; and Sections 33 and 34, T. 18, R. 5 - a total of 488 acres. Enclosed you will find Township Plan with the property in question marked in blue.

Before final arrangements can be made with the present owners, I wish to have a valuation of the property by an independent valuator and I should be pleased if you would undertake the commission of appraisal for the Department. The valuation should show the actual present value of the land in question, the main and other school buildings, furniture, machinery, farm implements and livestock. The church and rectory near the school are not situated on the parcel of land that we are purchasing.

It is the Department's wish that the transfer be completed in the near future and I shall be grateful if you will undertake this work at your earliest convenience. Please advise me if you will act for us in this connection and indicate the probable date of your valuation and report.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Otis Holden, Esq.,
Indian Head,
Sask.

OWESSESS BOARDING SCHOOL.

I visited this school on the 23rd June accompanied by Agent Pugh. This school is under the auspices of the Roman Catholic church. The Principal, the Rev. J. Carriere O.M.I. is assisted in his work by six sisters, two of whom are teachers, a lay brother and a mechanic.

Building. The main building is brick with a basement and three stories. The basement provides play-rooms, kitchen, dining room and laundry. The first floor provides office, staff room and two bright classrooms. The second floor provides a sewing room infirmary and staff room, and the top floor provides dormitories. There is...
splendid separation between the boys' and girls' dormitories. The building is steam heated, and lighted with electricity and is well equipped. There is an abundant supply of good water available. I found the building scrupulously clean throughout.

Attendance. There are 82 pupils enrolled, all but four of whom were present. They were neatly dressed and presented a clean and well nourished appearance. They were dressed for the occasion and were very neatly clothed. I had called at this school unexpectedly on the evening of the 19th and saw the children in their everyday clothing which I found clean and good.

Food. There is plenty of good wholesome food provided including all the milk the children desire. A large garden supplies all their vegetable requirements and these form an important item of the children's diet.

The crop sown this year consists of 65 acres of wheat, 43 acres oats, 30 acres barley and 6 acres of garden stuff and potatoes. The grain and vegetable crops look fine and there is an excellent prospect for an abundant yield.

The cattle number over 50 head. They were milking 15 cows. The stock provides a large proportion of their meat supply and butter. They keep a large...
flock of poultry and the produce from their farm and stock is an important factor in keeping down the expense of carrying on the work.

In my opinion this school is being conducted in a satisfactory manner. The general appearance and atmosphere of the institution shows that the Principal and his staff take a pride and interest in their duties.

Respectfully submitted,

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Valuation of the Land.

The land in question on sections 5 and 8, Township 19A, Range 5, West 2nd. This consists of 206 acres. 150 acres of this land is under cultivation and it is also in good condition.

The crop at the present time on this land is good and their garden is extra.

About 56 acres is pasture land. This 56 acres in my opinion is too low for cultivation.

Therefore the price of 206 acres @ $30 per acre is $6180.00

Of the land in sections 3 and 4, Township 19A, Range 5, and sections 33 and 34, Township 19, Range 5, (282 acres), about 200 acres is under cultivation. 25 acres is wasteland on the bank of the valley and 57 acres of hayland. This land is not in a good state of cultivation.

Therefore 282 acres @ $25 per acre $7050.00

Dear Mr. Scott:

Enclosed you will please find my valuation of the Cowessess Indian Residential School at Marieval.

I found the school building in a good state of repair, and the contents in the best of order.

The ice house listed at $1200 to you by the Oblate Fathers is cut out of my valuation as they claim it was donated to them by the Government in 1924.

The farm house listed to you as 14' x 14' has had an addition added, making it 14' x 28'.

I checked up both bedding and clothing, also cotton and other materials in stock. I found much more than the Oblate Fathers listed to you. But as you did not ask me to value these I am sending no valuation on them.

I find the valuation the Fathers put on this property very reasonable except on a few articles.
The School could not be built at the present time for the amount they have valued it at. That is, with the steam heating system, the electric lights, and the cesspool or septic tank, which I consider part of the equipment of the building; also the plumbing system and fixtures throughout the building.

This is not a new building, although in the very best state of repair, and I consider that $40,000.00 is a very fair valuation, I consider with the heating, plumbing, septic tank and the lighting system that the building is worth at least $40,000.00.

Yours truly,

Samuel Otis Holden

It is the intention to acquire title to 206 acres in Sections 5 and 8, T. 19 A., R. 5, W. 2nd, on which the school buildings are situate, and 282 acres in Sections 3 and 4, T. 19 A., R. 5, and in Sections 33 and 34, T. 18, R. 5 - a total of 488 acres. The classroom work is carried on in two class rooms, one for the boys and one for the girls. Sister Arsenious is in charge of the girls' room in which work is carried on from Grade 1 to Grade 6. The roll calls for 42 pupils and the attendance is good. The sister I understand is a qualified teacher and the class work was good considering the children had just returned from holidays.

The work in the boys' room is in charge of sister St. Odilon who is also qualified. There are 36 boys enrolled and the register showed the attendance to be good. The grades range from 1 to 6, and the children appeared to understand their work and to be properly graded. I was surprised to find the Dominion Catholic Readers and other text books being used and not the Saskatchewan text books.

The building throughout was clean and the work in the various departments progressed under splendid order and with apparently little effort on the part of those in charge.

The new boiler room, although not completed, was well under way and is one of the finest I have seen. It - is built about -

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
is built about twenty feet from the main building and joined by an underground passage. The basement is twelve feet underground and measures about 32' x 42'. Part of this basement is to be used as a root cellar; while the other half is taken up with the furnace and boiler. The ground floor is used as a workshop and storage room for the electric light plant, while above this, sleeping accommodation is made for the night watchman and furnace man. The danger from fire is practically eliminated due to the location of the building and its construction.

Since my last visit the horse barn has been refloored with cement and is now in good condition. The new chicken house was badly needed and will undoubtedly be made good use of.

A hog barn is also needed, as the old buildings now in use are a disgrace and should be removed.

About twelve cows are being milked at the present time and this gives plenty of milk for the needs of the school.

The crops this year in the valley are very poor and the Reverend Father Carrier informed me that all told he only threshed about 450 bus. of grain.

I was present at the noon-day meal and there appeared plenty of well prepared food which the children enjoyed and which undoubtedly satisfied them.

I believe this school is well managed, and one could not help but be pleased with the conditions and with the care and supervision given to the children.

Sir:

For many years it has been the custom for the Indian parents of children attending the Cowessess Indian Residential School to visit the school at any time but the more especially on Sunday and take their children from the school to their homes or camps and eat a meal with them, sometimes staying with them several hours.

While this procedure has been fairly satisfactory and has never led to a great deal of trouble I know it is not customary at most residential schools and I do not approve of it. Fr. Carriere however was always loathe to change fearing meeting with the ill will of the parents.

Fr. Chatelaine, Acting Principal, spoke to me one day last week stating that he wished to make a rule that the children would not be permitted to visit in their own homes in the future during the regular school term except under special circumstances and asked my opinion of the matter. I informed him that I was quite in accord with the idea and that I was sure the Department would concur. Yesterday being the first Sunday since this decision was made Fr. Chatelaine informed the Indians of his intentions which immediately roused their ire.

Today a number of Indians visited my office to meet Fr. Chatelaine in my presence to go into the matter more fully. I discussed the matter thoroughly with them giving reasons why I considered Fr. Chatelaine quite correct in trying to enforce this rule. Of thirteen parents present in my office 3 agreed with what Fr. Chatelaine had suggested and 10 were contrary.

I do not know whether it is the wish of the Department to enforce a rule of this kind against the wishes of the parents but I would like to see Fr. Chatelaine receive the utmost support and commendation in any effort he may make to improve the discipline of this school and this is only a first step in the right direction. Many times in the past the sisters at the school have informed me that allowing the children to go home for even short periods often gives them a great deal of extra work with vermin, sickness etc. and they were never in accord with Fr. Carriere in the matter.

I would be glad to receive the Department's instructions in the matter.

Your obedient servant

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st instant, with reference to the custom of allowing the pupils of the Cowessess Indian Residential School to visit their parents occasionally.

The Department regrets that this practice has prevailed at the Cowessess Residential School. It is realized that it must cause considerable inconvenience to the staff and, also, disarrange the classroom work. At the same time, when the Indians insist on it being continued, there may be difficulty in wholly stopping it.

Has the same practice prevailed at the Round Lake Indian Residential School? Please make definite inquiries regarding this and advise the Department. If such practice has prevailed, it might be advisable for you to hold a meeting with the Principals of both schools and consider what is the best action to take in future. The Department feels that the practice should be totally discontinued or, at least, only one day a week, preferably Sunday, should be set aside for parents either to visit their children at the school or for the children to go home for a few hours.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 108-2-1 of the 26th ultimo in connection with the visiting of pupils of the Cowessess Indian Residential School during the school term.

With regard to your question regarding the children of the Round Lake Indian Residential School I would say that the system followed at this school regarding visiting leaves nothing to be desired as the occasions of children spending part of the day at the homes of their parents during the regular school term are very rare and rightly so.

Reverend Fr. Chatelaine informs me that he enforced the rule at his school last Sunday, the 27th, and there was only mild protest from a few Indians, possibly because they knew that I had written the Department about the matter and was awaiting a reply.

I think that if the Department make a definite ruling that the children must not visit their homes during the regular term without special permission, but permitting the parents to visit the school as arranged with the Reverend Principal, to see their children on the school grounds, there will be little further trouble.

Your obedient servant,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

In reply to Dept. letter 108-2-5, of Feb. 27th, re building of a cold storage at Cowessess Boarding School, I beg to state that Mr. Neatman, the successful tenderer is now residing at the Pacific coast.

It would be impossible to have this building completed by the first of April in any case, owing to the danger from frost. The painting would have to be done in fine weather as well as the cement work. No contractor would guarantee the work if undertaken before the 15th of April.

The material could be placed on the ground before the first of April, however, and Mr. Neatman's representative at Grayson would see to this at once. Kindly advise me by wire as to the decision of the Department, in order that the material may be moved while the roads are yet good for sleighing.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of the 14th instant with reference to the contract for the erection of the cold-storage building in connection with the Cowessess Indian boarding school.

In reply I beg to say that this contract was awarded Mr. Frank Westman for the sum of $1,100.00. Between the time of the acceptance of his tender and passing of the necessary Order in Council, our agent informed us that Mr. Westman had left Greyson, Sask., and gone to reside at the coast, and that his business was being conducted by Mr. F. W. Terry, who signed the contract as his agent. Mr. Terry successfully completed the work and payments were made to him.

I trust this explanation will be satisfactory. I may say that Mr. MacKenzie showed the original papers to Mr. Reid yesterday. Payments were made on the certificate of our Architect, based upon reports of the agent; these also were shown to Mr. Reid. I shall ask the Architect, however, to bear in mind the fact that when he makes payments of this kind a copy of the report of our agent or other officer should accompany the progress certificate.

Yours very truly,

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter #55996-9 dated Feb 3rd, 1926 in reference to a fire which occurred at the Cowessess Indian Residential School on the 13th November, 1925, and in reply I beg to state I have not officially reported this fire to the Department or the Indian Commissioner, I only reported the fire in my December report.

I would state that I was not notified by the Principal and I received my information of the fire one week after its occurrence from the Commissioner's office in Regina. I saw the Principal at this time and he advised me that he notified his Head Quarters and they were to notify the Department, and I therefore let matters stand at that and only made mention of the fire in my report for December.

In regard to the fire I would advise that the source of it was brought to light yesterday the 11th Feb., when after receiving the Department's letter, I made arrangements with R.C.M.P. to pick up ex-pupil Jimmy Kesecsepe, 17 years of age, of whom I had had reports of behavior around reserves, and also from information obtained from the school, and after a considerable time the boy was brought into the office here, and the R.C.M.P. Sgt. Richardson took an admission of guilt that he set the fire in the Electric Shop, using gasoline out of a pail and pouring it between the walls, and firing paper. One other boy was with him, Sampson Feltier, age 15 years.

The location of the fire was in the wall of the Electric Shop, Laundry and Boiler room, the damage consisted of the wall only, to the ceiling, and some belting. No other damage was done.

The fire was got under control by chemicals and water. All the children were gotten out safely by the fire escape in a few minutes. The whole building was enveloped in smoke, but fortunately did not flame as all doors were kept shut. The Electric Shop, Laundry and boiler room are in a lean to on to the proper building.

I understand that insurance has been paid for the damage caused, and I note that the partition burnt out has been rebuilt in concrete.

In regard to the extinguishers I would advise that they have 12 small hand Pyrene extinguishers. There have been eight refilled and chemical is being supplied for the other four, but the number is thought to be inadequate, hence the request for a further supply. The condition of those on hand is good.
In regard to the boy apprehended for this fire I beg to advise that Sgt. Richardson has this boy in custody and is taking the matter up through his Head quarters in Regina and Indian Commissioner Graham. It is however my recommendation that the boy be sent to a Reformatory as I consider he is a dangerous boy to be at large.

I trust this is the information desired and regret that I was negligent in not reporting the matter properly, but I have no doubt that the Department will understand the position I was in, through not having the co-operation of the Principal in the matter of reporting.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
