On the 26th January 1926 I was on patrol in company with Mr. J.S. Pugh, Indian Agency, Crooked Lakes Agency, and on talking to Father Carriere, the Principal of the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School at Crooked Lake, learned that a fire had occurred at the school on the morning of the 13th November 1925, under very suspicious circumstances, and that damage to the extent of about $600.00 was done, before it was put under control. It was thought by Father Carriere that Jimmy Kesecapeew, a pupil of the school, had started the fire. This youth who is about 17 years of age, was discharged from the School by Father Carriere, just before Christmas, on account of thieving, breaking out of school, could not be trusted and was setting a very bad example to the other children attending. Mr. Pugh and myself interviewed some of the elder boys at the school, with a view of finding out who started the fire. The only thing we were able to get, was that the boys thought Jimmy had started the fire, and that on several occasions he had broken out of school at night, and stolen certain small articles. We learned that Jimmy was away from the Reserve, visiting his sisters on The Little Bones Reserve at Crescent Lake, South of Yorkton, Sask., so we decided to await his return to the Sakimay Reserve & interview him. On the 14th February we informed Mr. Pugh that this boy had called at his office, and had detained him, so that I could interview him. I drove me to the Agency per private auto, and I obtained the following statement of Jimmy Kesecapeew:

"I am an ex-pupil of the R.C. School at Crooked Lake, Saskatchewan Indian Reserve, and am seventeen and a half years old. I was discharged from the School about six months ago. I have got up in the middle of the night several occasions, whilst at the school, and was caught by Father Carriere once, coming down the stairs. I stole the leggings belonging to the school, by breaking a lock on the cupboard door. Joe Williams was with me the night when Father Carriere caught us on the stairs.

On the 24 prior to the summer holidays, I tried to set fire to the school by lighting a roll of toilet paper in the dormitory. The paper burnt out before it had caused fire to the building. One night in November 1925 I went with Samson Pelletier (another pupil) and we went upstairs, when I set fire to the school. We went upstairs, into the dining room, through the kitchen and boiler room. I went up on the roof of the boiler room, which is a lean-to, against the school proper, and got matches. I could not find a place to light them, so got down and went back to the boiler room. Samson was. I got a can of coal oil or gas-oil and sprinkled it on the board partition between the shop and the boiler room. I climbed up on the..."
bricks atop of the boiler, and pushed some paper into the corner of the boards, and then set fire to the paper. I waited to see if it had got a good start and after about 15 minutes returned to the dormitory. A little smoke was coming into the dormitory. Jimmy was with me all the time. We were in stocking feet. Gabriel Accosee woke me and then the children were all filled out. We were awake about an hour from the dormitory. The reason I set light to the school was on account of Brother Macdonald struck me on the nose and knocked me over, because I swore at him. This made me sore. Father Carriere also strapped me and it also made me sore. I made up my mind that on account of the whipings, that I would set fire to the School."

(Signed) Jimmy Kesecapeew.

On learning the above, Mr. Pugh, the interpreter, Jimmy & myself proceeded to the R.C. School at Crooked Lake, where I obtained the following statement from Samson Pelletier, who stated as follows:

"I am a pupil of the Roman Catholic Residential School at Crooked Lake. I am an Indian boy and am 15 years of age. I know Jimmy Kesecapeew, he used to be a pupil at the school. I remember the night of the fire; it was before Christmas. I woke Jimmy up this night on his suggestion, about 2 o'clock. I came downstairs with Jimmy, he was in stocking feet and I was barefooted. We went down to the electric room. I was with him all the time. He had a coil of something in his hand, and then poured some between the rafters & walls and then set light to it with a match. It had started to blaze, and after a few minutes we returned to the dormitory. There was a little smoke in the boys dormitory when we got there. We went to bed. I saw Jimmy wake up the boys. I think he spoke to Gabriel Accosee. I have not spoken to anybody about the fire until today."

(Signed) Samson Pelletier.

I then obtained a statement from Father Carriere as follows: - I am the Principal of the Roman Catholic Residential School at Crooked Lake, Sask. About 1.34 p.m. of the 13th November 1916 I was notified by Brother Sanford, that there was a fire at the school. I went to the dormitories, and in the boy's dormitory there was a little smoke. There was no smoke in the girl's dormitory. On my instructions the girls were got out of the building by the fire escape. The boys at this time were out. I then went to the electrical shop where the fire was, where I was saw some of the staff and some of the elder boys, hauling water to put out the fire. All the fire extinguishers were used. Damage was done to partitions, ceilings and some of the machinery etc., to the amount of about $800.00. The insurance was $250.00. The fire was very large but out, and it was a wonder the whole school did not go. I phoned the head office at Winnipeg about the fire. I did not suspect anybody at the time of the fire. Since the fire a guard has been placed around the building at night. The doors as far as I know were all locked on the night of the fire. Jimmy Kesecapeew, an ex-pupil was discharged from the School on account of not being able to trust him. He was a dangerous example to the other pupils. (Signed) J. Carriere, Principal."
I then learned from Father Carrier, a guard who was on night duty, about a week after the fire had heard someone run across the roof of the lean-to, and on looking around outside, saw some person in the distance, but could not get near him. This guard was armed, but he did not shoot at the object. In order to clear up this point to find who would be around at this time of night, I again interviewed Jimmy Kesecapew, and he stated that about a week after the fire he again came down and went outside on the roof of the building, climbed to the roof with some paper saturated with gasoline to start a fire, but did not do so. On account I had no matches. The paper was thrown away. I also learned from Father Carrier that the wood pile which at that time was against the end of the lean-to had been either sprinkled with gasoline or coal oil. I then interviewed Joseph William, another pupil of the school who stated that Jimmy and he had broke out of the school one night, and wandered over the Reserve and returned before the other boys had arose. On another occasion they had gone down to steal leggings from the cupboard. Mr. Pugh informs that Jimmy admits the theft of two sets of harness from Indian farmers, one of which he cut up to make whips with. This boy's mother is a widow, and lives on the Sakimay Reserve, and apparently has no control over him. He wanders from place to place, and gets a meal where he can. Last fall he was brought back by Mr. Pugh & myself from Crescent Lake for running away from the School. It appeared to both myself and Mr. Pugh that this boy is dangerous to be at large, so I detained him and brought him to Broadview, where he is now still in my charge.

As will be seen by the above this is the third attempt to burn down this School by this boy Jimmy Kesecapew. In the second attempt it was very lucky it was got under control, if it gone very quick, there is no doubt there would have been loss of life. He was also very lucky that the fire did not get into when he was around the building about a week after the fire. All the doors were closed and the only way he could have got out of the building was by the fire escape, and there is no doubt this is the way he returned.

The other boy Sam Pelletier had nothing whatever to do with the fire, outside of assisting Jimmy. He has a very good reputation in the camp. He thought Jimmy was on one of his escapades, and after he saw what Jimmy had scared he would be implicated, and did not say anything about what he knew. Mr. Pugh gave him a good lecture about this, which I think had a good effect.

I will detain this boy until further notice by telephone, and await instructions.

The Officer Commanding,
R.C.Mounted Police,
Southern Sask.District.

SPECIFICATIONS OF LABOUR AND MATERIALS REQUIRED IN THE ERECTION AND COMPLETION OF A COLD STORAGE FOR THE COWESSES INDIAN BOARDING SCHOOL, MARIEVAL, VIA GRAYSON, SASK., ACCORDING TO PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS PREPARED FOR SAME BY THE ARCHITECT OF THE DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS, OTTAWA.

GENERAL CONDITIONS.

CHARACTER OF WORK.

All of the various works to be executed in a substantial and workmanlike manner, and of the best materials and workmanship of their several kinds, in accordance with the drawings, specifications and instructions given from time to time; and all of the said works are to be carried out and completed to the full and entire satisfaction of the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, through the intermediary of his Architect or authorized Supervisor.

CERTIFICATES.

Certificates will be issued and payment made on the contract at the rate of 90% of the value of the work done, balance to be paid 30 days after the full and satisfactory completion of the work.

SITE.

All parties tendering must examine the site on which the building is to stand, prior to sending in their tenders, and make themselves thoroughly acquainted with the same, and obtain for themselves any and all information respecting any work required, before building.
building operations can be started, as no after-claim will be allowed or entertained for any work necessary to remove obstructions in order to commence operations.

All parties tendering before sending in their tenders must ascertain for themselves the nature of the materials to be excavated and the amount of grading and nature thereof in accordance with specifications. The Department does not guarantee any information furnished the Contractor regarding the nature of the material to be excavated.

SUPERVISION—

The Contractor is to give his personal supervision to the work, to set out the work to the correct dimensions and position on the site and to proper level, and to furnish all necessary materials, labour, apparatus, scaffolding, and utensils required in or used for performing the work in the best and most satisfactory manner according to the drawings and these particulars prepared for same.

There should be a competent foreman on the work continually during working hours, who shall be fully empowered to act for the Contractor during his absence.

MATERIAL AND WORKMANSHIP—

All materials used in the work to be Canadian (that is if they can be obtained in Canada) and to be new and of the best quality of the several kinds.

Should the Contractor introduce any material different from the sort and quality herein described, it shall, on notice, be immediately removed at the Contractor's expense at any time during the progress of the works.
WAGES.

Intending for the work herein contemplated, the tenderers when called upon to enter into a contract, will be bound to pay the workmen engaged in said work, wages as are generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is being carried out, and the said tenderers after having signed the contract will be held and bound to conform themselves to the wording and spirit of this clause. All workmen employed upon the work comprehended in and to be executed pursuant to the said contract, shall be residents of Canada, unless the Superintendent General is of the opinion that Canadian labour is not available, or that emergencies or other special circumstances exist which render it contrary to public interest to enforce the foregoing conditions in respect to the employment of resident Canadian workmen. The Contractors shall not assign or sublet this contract without the written consent of the Superintendent General first obtained, providing, however, that the Contractors may sublet such portions of the work herein contracted for as is customary and usual in the construction of such works, but the Department will not in any way be held liable for the payment of any moneys due to any sub-contractors, and the Contractors shall be held responsible for the proper performance of every portion of the work herein contracted for.

3.
INTERPRETATION.

The work to be executed in the best and most satisfactory manner according to the true intent and meaning of the plans and specifications, which are intended to include everything requisite and necessary for the full and entire completion of the works without exception, notwithstanding that every item necessarily involved in the works is not particularly mentioned, and work shown and not specified or vice versa, is to be done as if both shown and specified.

Any work or material obviously necessary for the proper completion of the work, although not specified herein, is to be done or supplied by the Contractor without additional charge, it being understood that the amount of the tender covers everything necessary for a complete and first-class job.

ADDITIONS OR DEDUCTIONS.

No deviations from the plans or specifications will be permitted without the direct consent of the Department in writing, and no extras will be considered unless authorized by the Department in writing, and the prices agreed on before the work is commenced. Extra work and deductions, if any, to be at the rate paid for the original contract.

Should the Department at any time during the progress of the works desire any alterations, additions, or omissions, from the work as provided for in the plans and specifications, the Architect, with the approval of the Deputy Superintendent General, shall have the right to issue orders and directions in the matter, and the same
same shall in no way affect or make void the contract. No such alterations, additions or omissions shall be instituted, without authority in writing.

RESPONSIBILITY:

The Contractor shall be held liable for all violation of laws caused by obstruction of roads, etc., and must give the proper authorities all requisite notice and pay any fees or expenses in connection therewith, and shall be responsible for all accidents to workmen engaged about the building during construction, and hold the Department harmless from any damage or expense arising therefrom. The work during its performance to be properly protected by the Contractor who will be held responsible for all accidents that may happen to individuals or animals in the consequence of the non-fulfilment of this condition.

The Contractor at completion to remove all waste material and debris from the premises and shall leave all clean and in a proper condition and given up in a complete and undamaged state without exception.

Should any question arise as to the meaning of any portion of the plans or specifications, the same shall be referred to the determination of the Architect of this Department, and his decision shall be final without exception.

The Department does not bind itself to accept the lowest or any tender.

5.
MASONRY.

EXCAVATION

Excavate to the depth, form and size as shown on plan for all walls and drains. Excavation to be made one foot larger than walls, etc., to allow for footings and the building up of walls.

GRADING—

The excavated earth will be stacked on the lot and levelled at completion to the grade directed and required, firmly tamping the earth solid around all walls.

FOOTINGS—

The concrete foundation walls to have a footing course of concrete 6" thick and projecting at least 6" on each side of wall above.

FORMS—

Build forms of the dimensions of footing course and wall where shown. The forms to be erected straight, level and perpendicular, and to be strongly supported and braced.

WALLS—

Build walls of the height and thickness shown formed of grout, composed of 1 part of Canada Cement Company's Portland cement, 2 parts of clean sharp sand, and 4 parts of clean washed screened gravel or broken stone to a size that will pass through a 2½" ring and a sufficient quantity of clean water to make the mass of the consistency of mortar.

6.
MIXING, Etc.,

The cement and sand to be mixed dry by frequent shovelling from one pile to another until thoroughly incorporated, then to add the gravel and again mix dry, until gravel, sand, and cement are uniformly distributed, then add water and mix until of the proper consistency.

The fittings and walls are to be filled into forms and tamped hard until water shows freely on surface. The walls are to be built up in layers about 6" thick and immediately rammed until the water flushed to the top. Each layer is to be deposited before the preceding one becomes dry, and in each case the top surface is to be well wet before a new layer is put on.

All walls are to be kept well wetted while the work is in progress and to be protected from the heat and well wetted daily for at least two weeks after completion of the concrete. The framework of the building is not to be placed on concrete until it is two days old.

CEMENT FINISH,

When the foundation is complete and frame laid, the whole of the exterior of foundation wall above grade line, will be finished with coat of cement in proportion of 1 of cement to 3 of clean washed sharp sand mixed as before specified. This coat to be laid on with sufficient force to secure thorough adhesion, floated to a smooth and even surface. The concrete work to be covered and kept well wetted for at least twelve hours before putting on finishing coat.
ANCHOR BOLTS.

Provide and fix in concrete 5/8" x 12" anchor bolts, nut and washer every 4' apart around building and going through a 2 x 4" plate as shown on plan. Carpenter will bore holes in plate.
CARPENTRY AND JOINERY.

MATERIALS.

The whole of the lumber used to be sawn die square and free from sap, shakes, and loose or dead knots, the timber for joiners' use to be particularly dry and well seasoned. The whole of the timber must hold to the dimensions shown or figured on drawings and in specifications. All of the materials used for construction work to be pine, spruce, hemlock or fir, and finishing work, pine or fir unless otherwise specified.

SILLS.

The sills for frame will of two by four inch firmly and evenly bedded level on concrete wall as shown and securely bolted as before specified.

JOISTS.

All joists to be carefully sized before laying so as to secure an even and level floor and ceiling line.

ROOF.

The rafters will be of 2 x 6" set at 24" centres, framed at heel and well and strongly spike-nailed to plates and together with 4" spike-nails and having ridge board full length to which rafters will be nailed. Cover rafters with good quality rough boarding, well nailed with at least two 3" nails to each board at each crossing of rafters. Cover boarding with best quality British Columbia cedar shingles laid 4½" to the weather.
FLOOR IN ICE CHAMBER.

The area of the floor in the ice chamber will be graded with a slope of 3° to one corner. Lay rows of field tile 3' apart leading to the low corner and connect same to drain outside building, the connecting to be trapped to prevent the passage of air. Cover the tile with 9" of stone and 3" of cinders or clean gravel. On top of cinders lay loose boards. This forms the permanent floor of ice chamber and provides drainage for the melting ice. Before ice is placed in chamber, the floor is to be covered with 12" of planing mill shavings.

FLOOR IN ANTE-ROOM AND REFRIGERATOR.

Cover area of floors with 6 to 5" of coal cinders or dry sand or gravel. Lay 7/8" tongued and grooved floor on 2 x 4" joists. Cover with damp-proof building paper and then place 2 x 6" joists 24" centres. Fill space between joints with planing-mill shavings and cover with 1½" flooring tongued and grooved.

WALLS OF ICE CHAMBER, REFRIGERATOR, AND ANTE-ROOM.

Erect two rows 2 x 4" studs staggered so as to leave a space of 12" between inside and outside sheeting to be filled with shavings. Cover the outside with one course of 7/8" tongued and grooved lumber, two plies of felt building-paper and finish with siding or clapboards. Cover the inside of studs with two courses of 7/8" tongued and grooved spruce sheeting with two plies of damp-proof paper between them.

NOTE.— Only SPRUCE LUMBER to be used for the inside finish of refrigerators and ice-chamber.

CEILING.

Erect 2 x 5" joists 24" centres. Cover under side of joints with two courses of 7/8" tongued and grooved spruce sheathing with two plies of damp-proof paper between. Fill space behind joists with shavings as shown on plans and cover with two courses of 7/8" tongued and grooved sheathing with two plies of paper between.

PARTITIONS.

Partitions between ice-chamber and ante-room and between ice-chamber and refrigerator and ante-room, to be constructed with 2 x 6" studding, covered on both sides with two courses of 7/8" tongued and grooved sheathing with two plies of felt paper between. Wall to be filled with planing-mill shavings.

DOORS.

The door from ante-room into refrigerator and ante-room to ice-chamber, to be fitted with bevelled frames as shown on plans. Make the doors bevelled to fit frame with two course of 7/8" spruce sheathing both inside and outside with 4" space filled with shavings. The bevelled space of all doors to be covered with felt to make as nearly as possible an air-tight joint.

The outside door into ante-room to be doubled as shown on plan with weight box and weights, to keep doors closed. All doors to be fitted with necessary hinges and locks complete.

DOOR FRAMES.

Outside door frames to be of 2" pine with hardwood sill as shown to detail.

- 10½ -
WINDOW.

Make a window 2 x 2' in ante-room opposite door in the refrigerator so as to allow light to enter the refrigerator when door is open. The window to be fitted with double sash well battened as shown on plan.

OPENING FOR AIR VENTILATION.

Make two openings 18" x 6" in the partition between ice-chamber and refrigerator. Place an opening at ceiling of refrigerator and other at the floor. Fit each opening with a sliding cover.

SHAVINGS.

Dry planing-mill shavings are to be used for filling all spaces where shown and required. They should be packed sufficiently to prevent subsequent settling.
PAINTING and GLAZING.

PAINTING.— Paint all the exposed wood and iron-work (interior and exterior) usually painted, three good coats of lead and oil tinted as directed. Refrigerator and ante-room to be white.

The lead to be used to be best Canadian white lead, of Brandram-Henderson's manufacture, or approved Canadian manufacture equal thereto, with pure boiled linseed oil and pure turpentine as dryer.

All work requiring it to be carefully knotted with best shellac before priming. When priming coat is dry, the work to be carefully stepped with best white lead putty and sand-papered, also to be rubbed down after second coat where rough, and finished with a flowing coat of lead and oil tinted as directed. The work to be finished in two colours and each coat to be thoroughly dry and hard before putting on other coat.

GLAZING.— The whole of the windows throughout the building to be glazed with English double diamond sheet glass of Pilkington manufacture.

All glass to be sprigged, bedded, and back and front putted.

PUTTY.— The putty used for glazing to be best white lead putty. The whole of the work to be done in a good and satisfactory manner.

SHINGLE STAINING.— The whole of the shingles to be used on the building to be dip stained 2/3 of their length before laying with best quality (moss green) Cabot creosote stain or other approved manufacture equal thereto.

Crime Report

Re - JIMMY KEECOAPNEW, Siksika Indian Reserve,
Crooked Lakes Agency, Broadview, Sask.

Further to my report of the 12th inst.

On the 13th inst., I received instructions by telephone, from Sgt. R.E. Mercer, Regina, to lay a charge of Arson against the above named youth, and get him remanded, & escort him to Regina.

On the same day I laid a charge against Jimmy Keecoopnew, that he on or about the 13th day of November 1925, did wilfully set fire to the Roman Catholic Indian Residential School at Crooked Lake, Sask. Contrary to Section 311 of the Criminal Code of Canada. The accused was taken before A. Sinclair J.P. at Broadview, on this date, and a request for a remand was granted till the 2 p.m. of the 26th inst.

On the same date I escorted this prisoner from Broadview to Regina, per C.P.R. train, Transport Requisition Book No. 24 & 25, and handed him over to the N.C.O. in Charge of the Night Guard at the R.C.M.P. Barracks, and obtained the following receipt:

"Received from Reg. No. 5111 Sergt. Richardson, C. the living body of prisoner Jimmy Keecoopnew."

COWESSESS INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

This school was inspected February 1st, 1927. Rev. Father Carriere was away on our arrival, but returned shortly after the noon hour, when I inspected the class rooms.

The boys were in one room in charge of Sister St. Pierre. This room was well ventilated and spotlessly clean. The boys were well clothed and clean. The desks, books and other equipment are well kept.

The girls are in charge of Sister St. Phillippe. This room also was very tidy and clean. The

desks
desks, although about 10 yrs. old, are spotless and scarcely a scratch can be seen on them. The school books are neatly kept and free from any disfiguring marks. The girls were well dressed, tidy and clean. In both these rooms the discipline was excellent. The children read well and were not afraid to speak out. Their spelling and other work examined was good and I believe fair progress is being made. The blinds in the boys' class room are worn out and useless.

The entire school was exceptionally clean and presented a splendid appearance. The dormitories especially, deserve mention; the girls' beds were beautifully made and the spreads were "white", not yellow or grey in appearance as one sees in many schools. The boys' beds were equally as nice, but with colored spreads.

In all the departments, the work was exceptionally well done and the discipline and order could not be excelled. Every department was in splendid shape and the work well up to the mark, and yet no one appeared rushed or overworked. Undoubtedly, a splendid system is carried out in this school. I would like to mention the work done in the laundry and sewing room. The washings could not be done better, and when ironed they showed that the work had been supervised by one who understood and knew her work. In the sewing room I found suits of clothes made for little boys and it was impossible to tell them from the ready made suits we buy. These, along with numerous dresses made by the girls, were neatly piled in cupboards and covered with white pieces of cotton. I have no doubt the Sister in charge could find any garment in the dark, so carefully were they arranged and stored away.
away.

The Rev. Principal claimed the engine used for pumping and running the lighting system was not satisfactory. The water supply tank is small, necessitating continual pumping. The engine is not strong enough to do this and run the lighting system and the other machinery at the school; consequently, either the work is held back, or the water supply runs short, or the batteries become low. In talking with the engineer, he claimed that a 12 H.P. engine would be necessary to carry the load of pumping, running the lighting system and the other machinery of the school. Before making any recommendation in regard to this, I feel that an expert should go over the situation, so that the actual need may be known.

The outbuildings at the school are very poor, with the exception of the main barn. This is a good building, but the horse stalls need re-flooring. The hen house and piggery now in use are old log buildings, and look about ready to fall down. The machine shed blew down last Fall, and rather than leave the machinery outside, the Rev. Principal erected a temporary covering. However, a machine shed is badly needed and should be large enough to accommodate the threshing machine, as well as the other machinery. In spite of these outbuildings being built of logs and in a very poor condition, they are kept whitewashed and tidy. The yard is clean, and everything showed care and attention.

A dairy herd of about 25 cows is kept at this school, and in addition, some 25 or 30 head of young cattle are being fed. The milk supply at present is low, but cows are expected to freshen at any time.

The Rev. Father
The Rev. Father Carriere is a hard worker, and is very interested in the school and children. I have no hesitation in saying I believe these children receive the very best of care and attention. Recently the children were sick with the 'Flu, but they are again looking quite well and appear happy and contented.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following short report on the Cowessess Boarding School, inspected July 6th, 1927.

On the day I visited this school all the children were home on holiday. The Sisters were also away and only the Reverend Father Carrier and his outside helpers were at the school. Although the Sisters were absent, everything was in excellent order and the place very clean and tidy.

The crop at the school looked very good. One field which was fallowed last year for the purpose of freeing it of twitch grass, had an excellent stand of wheat. Undoubtedly good work had been done on this fallow and although the twitch grass has not been entirely eradicated, its growth has been retarded so as to not interfere with this year's crop.

The ground about the school was tidy and well kept. The garden was in splendid condition.

In my last report a request was made for new blinds in one of the class rooms. The blinds are badly needed as the old ones are useless. If these were granted they might be hung during the holiday, so that the class room would be ready when re-opened.

The Reverend

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
The Reverend Father complained about the engine, used for pumping and lighting and power purposes, as being far too small. This engine has been in constant use for some years and I believe something will need to be done within the near future. However, I am not prepared to say just what will be needed. I feel this should be carefully gone over by an expert who understands engines thoroughly as well as the requirements of such a plant.

The horse barn floors need to be renewed as they are entirely worn through in places. The Reverend Father considers a board floor best, yet I would be inclined to recommend the use of cement so that a permanent job might be made.

The chicken house, pig pen, and granaries are all old log buildings past repair, and new ones are badly needed. This would greatly improve the surroundings.

I am inclined to feel that the Reverend Father Carrier is giving splendid service as Principal, and the boys who leave this school should be among our better farmers; in fact, some of our best young farmers starting this year are graduates of the Cowessess school.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the schools in the Crooked Lake Agency.

GOWESSSESS INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I inspected this school on January 27th, 1928.

The different classrooms are under the direction of two sisters, Sister St. Pierre Chrysologue and Sister St. Clement. The latter is a new member of the staff. She is in charge of the girls' classroom, and I believe good progress should be made under her instruction. She has a very pleasing manner and presents the various subjects in an attractive way.

Sister St. Pierre Chrysologue is in charge of the boys' classroom and good progress is certainly being made. I took particular notice of six small boys who only entered the school in September and are now able to speak English fairly well and have made splendid progress in writing. The work which these children have accomplished already is certainly a credit to any teacher. The children of both classrooms were exceptionally neat in appearance, and the classrooms were spotless.

The work which is carried on in the sewing room, laundry and kitchen is all exceptionally well done and apparently with little effort, either on the part of the pupils or the sisters in charge.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

The building throughout was clean and tidy; the dormitories were all well aired, and the beds presented a well cared for appearance.

Since my last inspection a new floor of cement has been laid in the horse barn. Excellent work was done in regard to this, and the barn is now in A1 condition, with the exception of it now needing paint badly. A new machine shed was erected last year which has not yet been painted.

A fairly large flock of poultry is kept at this institution, in spite of the fact that the chicken house now in use is an old log building, badly lighted, and in which one is unable to stand erect. A new building is certainly needed for the carrying on of this work. The pig pen is also a log building, very old in structure, and does not add to the appearance of the surrounding lay-out.

When I last visited this school, I found one of the best gardens I had seen during the summer. At this inspection, the Rev. Father Carriere, the Principal, informed me that it was rather discouraging to grow a large quantity of vegetables as no provision was made for a proper root cellar in which the vegetables might be kept during the winter months. It seems to me that when such an effort is put forth by those in charge of the school to have a good garden and lots of vegetables for the children, a proper root cellar should be provided so that these vegetables may be stored.

FIRE PROTECTION.

I went carefully into the question of fire protection, and found everything in splendid order with the exception of the fire hose. These are all very old and,
COWESSISS INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (Cont'd.)

Fire Protection (Cont'd.)

When the water is turned on, considerable pressure is lost as the hose leaks very badly. I think it would be well to replace the hose. To do this, it will require four hose, each 50 ft. long. In addition to this, I would recommend that two extra lengths of 50 ft. be furnished, to be used as extensions. At present there are six large fire extinguishers arranged in various prominent places throughout the building, as well as twenty small Pyrene extinguishers. The fire escapes are all in splendid condition, and at the fire drill carried out, it could readily be seen that the children were well accustomed to the use of the fire escapes.

At the present time about twelve cows are being milked for the use of the school children, and this number will be increased very shortly as there are a number of cows to freshen within the next month.

The children are undoubtedly provided with plenty of wholesome food, and at the time of inspection, there was no sickness in the building. Before I left the Agency Dr. Craig vaccinated all the children for Small-pox and inoculated them against Diphtheria. The children all appeared quite happy and looked exceptionally well, and no complaints of any kind were received as regards this school. The management of the school is carried on under the direction of the Rev. Father Carriere, and I believe excellent work is being done.
Regina, Sask., Feb. 16th, 1928.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report of an inspection of the two Boarding schools in the Crooked Lake Agency which was made by Mr. Inspector Hamilton during the latter part of January and the first week in February.

The first school reported on is the Cowessess Catholic Residential school, which is under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church and the Principalship of the Rev. Father Carriere. Regarding the Inspector's remarks concerning a henhouse and pigsty, an amount to provide for these buildings was placed in the Estimates, also for a root house. It seems to me, however, that it would not have taken much of an effort on the part of the Principal and his staff to have a root house erected, as there are a great many Indians living right near the school. A good root house was built at File Hills by the Principal.

Dear Mr. Scott:

You will recall a conversation we had with Father Carriere, the Principal of the Cowessess Indian Residential School, when you were here, regarding the building of a new engine house and workshop. It was pointed out by the Rev. Father that the building as it is was unsuitable for the purpose, because in the first place it was an old log building, attached to the brick building, and another storey could not be added to it to make room, as it would close off the light from the dormitories, and also it would only be a matter of a short time until the existing building would be condemned. I think we decided between us that a new building should be erected. I have gone into this matter now, and I believe that if we could get an appropriation of $3500.00 for this purpose a suitable building 40 x 30, with an upstairs which could be used as a workshop, and the downstairs for the housing of the steam boilers and engine could be built. This building would be situated about thirty feet from the main building, and would be connected by an underground passage to the basement. I really think this should be allowed, and I should be glad if you would have an item inserted in the Estimates to provide for it.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I wish to bring the following matter to your attention. When you were here last July you authorized me to have certain painting done at the Cowessess Indian Residential School, and I took steps immediately to have this done, and sent to the School a man by the name of Tappin, a painter, who had done certain work for us in other years, and he brought back an estimate of $1400.00 for doing the work outlined, under contract. This price seemed to me to be unreasonable, and I suggested that he do the work by day labour, which was agreed upon. After the work was completed he brought up a time sheet, duly certified to by Father Carriere as correct, and, on October 2nd., Regina Voucher No. 5451, for $576.00 was issued in favour of Mr. Tappin, and he was paid.

About two weeks ago Father Carriere came to my office and informed me that the time sheets which he had signed were incorrect, and that Tappin had overcharged for 215½ hours. Father Carriere pointed out that on some of the days where he had shown full time, viz:- 10½ hrs. he had really only worked three hours, and so on, and Tappin was paid for 1095 hours, whereas he should only have been paid for 579½ hours. Of this 215½ hours, 132½ hours consisted of time which he had put down on his time sheet, which he had actually done no work at all, and for which he was paid by the Department. The remaining 83 hours was time which he had spent in doing special work for Father Carriere, for which the Father paid him, and this time was also included in the time sheet which he submitted here.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

-Father-
Father Carriere can give no explanation other than that Mr. Tappin made the bills up himself and assured him that they were correct. He did not check them up with the time that he was keeping, as Tappin had given him to understand that he was doing the work under contract.

Tappin has deliberately put in false time sheets, and has been overpaid for 215½ hours, at 80¢ an hour, which amounts to $172.60, and I think some action should be taken to have him return the money.

I may say that when Father Carriere came here I sent for Mr. Tappin. He became very indignant and said that the Father did not know what he was talking about, and that he had his signature. It seems to me that even though the Father did make a mistake we should take some steps to have this money refunded, and I should be glad to have your instructions in the matter.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

I am also enclosing order on the Marshall-Wells Co. for pump and pressure tank. These are badly needed and, if possible, I would like to have them very soon.

I would like to draw your attention to the fact that the school is already out of pocket for the following items in connection with the work done:

- 4 teams hauling and digging: 36 days
- 2 men working: 36 "
- 1 man (engineer) working: 4 months
- Board and lodging: 4 men 2 "
- " 2 men: 4 "

This part of the cost of the work was freely given by the school and reduced the cost of the completed work a large amount and I am sure the Department will appreciate this.

Yours truly,

Rev. J. Carriere
October 24th, 1929.

Dear Mr. Graham;

The enclosed letter is the best I can do - To explain how we have over spent the amount allowed to us is not easy, because you have all the time sheets, and invoices for all materials, what can I add to this?

The only explanations that can be given is, as I told you, material was too high price and I told you about the accident building the wall in concrete, so men had to do more than double work - We have tried to save all the money we could, and watching the work very closely -

We have also over spent money allowed for painting, about $300.00. We did not know we had only $800.00 for painting - I am glad to say that if you would see all what we have done you will not believe that we have spent only the amount you know of; because I had a good contractor to value the whole work and himself had value the same work for over $10,000.00.

I am leaving today, so Mr. Graham do your best in our behalf.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) Rev. J. Carriere.

On the 7th of May last, under Department No. 108-2-5, authority was given to undertake certain work at the Cowessess Indian Residential School, which included providing an engine house and work shop with root storage facilities, painting, and the erection of a hog pen and chicken coop. The expenditure authorized therein was $5,800.00.

The Reverend Principal, Father Carriere, visited my office and I discussed with him the work to be done and the amounts allowed in each case. I had a long and thorough discussion with him and I felt satisfied when he left that he properly understood the situation. A week or two ago a number of accounts were submitted by him for payment, which clearly indicated that the appropriation allowed was being very greatly exceeded. I wrote him and drew his attention to the matter and told him that work must immediately cease, and requested him to explain why the extra expenditures had been incurred, as he intimated to me that the several appropriations were quite sufficient. I enclose the undermentioned vouchers for payment:

| 6395  | G. F. Stephens Co., Regina   | 43.57  |
| 6396  | Fairbanks-Morse Co., Winnipeg| 76.98  |

These vouchers aggregate $1,494.60. In addition, there are some Time Sheets, which the Principal omitted to forward, amounting to $443.15. Prior to the receipt of the above mentioned vouchers, the expenditure had already reached

[Signature]

Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
$6,031.33. The total expenditure to date, therefore, is $7,959.08. It will be seen, therefore, that there has been an over-expenditure of $2,127.08.

The Reverend Principal came to see me, but did not appear to be able to offer a satisfactory explanation of the circumstances, and appeared to be much confused as to the several amounts which had been allowed. I enclose copies of two letters addressed to me by him, dated the 24th October, in which he submits his explanations. The Reverend Principal has not been well for some little time and this may in a measure account for his having lost control.

While the expenditure allowed has been greatly exceeded, I am satisfied that the money has been well spent and that there has been no waste. It is clear, however, that, in arriving at his estimates of the cost of the work to be done, the Principal greatly under-estimated what appropriation would be required.

With his letters of the 24th instant, he enclosed an order addressed to Marshall-Wells Limited, of Winnipeg, requesting them to furnish him with a power pump for the Pneumatic Pressure Tank service, the cost of which I understand will be in the neighbourhood of $110.00. He claims that this is needed at once, but in view of the circumstances I need hardly say that I did not forward this order, as I could not possibly sanction any further expenditure. I do not know whether or not the department wish to authorize it. I should add that notwithstanding the expenditures which have already been incurred, the Principal has not provided for the storage of roots which was to have formed part of the work to be done at the school. I have informed him that the school will certainly have to bear the expense of this if it is provided.

The classroom work is carried on by two Sisters, one in charge of the boys and one with the girls. I was given to understand that they hold certificates for teaching. The Sister in the girls' room is obtaining good results. The grades range as follows:

- Grade I - 6 pupils
- " II - 9 "
- " III - 7 "
- " IV - 12 "
- " V - 4 "
- " VI - 2 "

Total 40
The Sister in charge of the boys' room is new since my last visit, but I would be inclined to feel that, with more experience, she will make a successful teacher. The grades are arranged as follows:

| Grade | Pupils |
|-------|--------|
| I     | 11     |
| II    | 8      |
| III   | 5      |
| IV    | 12     |
| V     | 5      |
| VI    | 2      |
| Total | 43     |

The children were all neat, well dressed, and tidy, and the classrooms were well aired, bright and cheerful.

The work in the various departments in the school is in charge of well qualified Sisters, and I found all the work to be well done. A quantity of fancywork and sewing is being made ready for the Regina Exhibition, and will be a credit to the Department.

Fire drill is observed and the children are familiar with the escapes. All equipment is in good repair. Another pressure tank is being installed, which will give a further supply of water in case of fire.

The new boiler room is now completed and is perfectly satisfactory, affording wonderful protection against fire.

A workshop is arranged for upstairs in the building covering the boiler room and root cellar. The boys are kept busy in this building during the cold stormy days of winter learning how to do wood work and to repair shoes and harness.

The Reverend
The Reverend Father has all the work so arranged that the boys do not have a lot of idle time and yet I do not mean that amusements are not also provided. The boys are kept busy during working hours and are made to realize that they are at school for a purpose.

A large number of cattle are stabled and at all times plenty of milk is available for the school.

I found the barns and outbuildings to be clean and in good repair.

The meals provided are wholesome, and there appeared to be plenty for all. The children were all well and one could not help but feel that they receive the best of care and attention.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

I visited this school on November 6th, and made a general inspection of the buildings and premises.

I found the school in excellent condition, and clean and tidy throughout.

The Rev. Father Carriere, O.M.I., is in charge as Principal, and is assisted by Rev. Father Devarenne. He has a competent engineer and farmer. The interior of the building is well looked after by a staff of qualified Sisters, two of whom act as teachers. These teachers have had many years experience and hold Model School diplomas. There are 72 pupils in attendance, 44 girls and 38 boys. These children presented a clean and well-nourished appearance. They have had practically no sickness in the school for some time. In addition to their classroom studies, the girls are taught sewing, knitting, and the making of clothing, as well as other domestic work. The girls are taught how to make bread, and I may say that when visiting the homes on the Cowessess Reserve, from which this school largely recruits its pupilage, I found a number of the women, who are ex-pupils of the school, making bread in preference to bannock, which is the customary manner of preparing the flour for food. I think I saw a larger proportion of bread makers amongst the housewives on this reserve than on any I have visited for some time. The boys assist in the garden and on the farm, and in caring for the stock. This school appears to be well managed, and the care given to the children is reflected in their happy appearance. I was present during their meal hours, and noted that they were supplied with ample wholesome, nourishing food. A sufficient number of milk cows are provided to supply ample milk for their requirements during both winter and summer seasons.

I examined the fire equipment, and found it in good condition. In addition to the hose supplied on each floor,
which is connected with the water system, they have fire extinguishers as well located on each floor in an easily accessible position. Fire escape routes are provided with exits from each floor, and regular training in the use of these escapes is given to the pupils. They have become very expert in the use of these escapes.

An abundant supply of excellent water is obtained from a well in close proximity to the building. Two 1,000 gal. pressure tanks are provided for water storage.

There have been a number of improvements to the buildings during the past two years. The new building, providing accommodation for the heating and lighting plant, as well as a work shop and shoe shop, is a good building and eminently satisfactory for its purpose.

I might point out that there is only one interior toilet provided for the boys, and that is upstairs in the building. They have three outside closets, which are hard to keep clean and are not sanitary; in fact, I found them in a filthy condition. I would suggest that it would be advisable to provide proper toilets for the boys. There is a suitable room at the end of the boys' playroom which would provide room for the installation of two toilets, as well as a shower bath. In the event of these being installed, a separate drain 150 ft. long to the septic tank would have to be provided, but the laundry water drainage could be attached to the same drain pipe, and this would eliminate the present system of draining the laundry water into a cess pool. It is estimated that this improvement would cost $600.00. The Principal will undertake the work with his own staff. I think that the installation of these toilets is very necessary, and

I would
I would strongly recommend that it be authorized.

A new hog house was built during the past summer. The plan of this building is one, I believe, which is supplied by the Government of British Columbia. I am of the opinion that this building will not prove satisfactory for our climate here. This building is 16 ft. wide and 72 ft. long; the front stud is 10 ft. and the rear 6 ft., with sloping roof. The walls are not lined on the inside of the studding; therefore, there is no air space. Two wall ventilators are supplied with openings near the floor of the building. I am satisfied that these ventilators will not give the necessary ventilation, and during the severe weather the result of lack of ventilation will mean that the walls will be covered with frost, and the building will be damp. As you know, hogs cannot be satisfactorily kept in a damp building. They are very susceptible to rheumatism, and it is necessary to have a dry, well ventilated building in order to raise hogs successfully. I am of the opinion that it will be necessary to line the walls of this building in order to provide an air space and ceil the roof so that there will be an air space there as well, and provide ventilators close to the ceiling of the building, in order to make this building satisfactory.

Their stock consist of 12 horses, 50 cattle, of which 17 are milk cows, 9 pigs and about 150 poultry. An ample supply of feed has been secured for the stock this year. This feed is not all grown on the farm and a considerable amount of hay is purchased to meet their requirements. Their garden provided an ample supply of potatoes and vegetables for their requirements.

A Sister is in charge of each room, and I believe good progress is made. The children speak out exceptionally well and can be heard distinctly across the room. They read well and are able to express themselves when questioned. Their work books are neat and splendid care is taken of all text books. The desks, although in use for years, are almost like new, and the rooms were clean and very tidy. The children were away for the Christmas holidays, but were back ready for school when it opened after the New Year.

The children were well dressed and neat in appearance. They appeared exceptionally healthy and are undoubtedly well fed and well cared for. There was no sickness of any kind.

The school throughout was spotlessly clean. The dormitories are well aired and tidy, and the beds neatly made. The bedding was clean. The children are supplied with night robes. The doors leading to the fire escapes are not locked, and a button wired to the fire alarm is placed in each dormitory.

The fire escapes are in good condition; also the hose. Extinguishers are placed throughout the building and fire drill observed regularly. The water supply is fair and I found good pressure throughout the building.

The girls are taught plain sewing and make not only their own clothes but also many garments for the boys. This department is well managed, and splendid work accomplished.

The kitchen is in
The kitchen is in charge of a Sister and the girls learn plain cooking, bread making and butter making. This is a heavy department, but no one appears overworked.

The laundry work is well done. The room is somewhat cramped, but well equipped. The drying room is above the laundry and very satisfactory. The drain from the laundry empties into a well some 40 feet away from the building. There is no outlet from this well and unless baled out backs up on the laundry floor. This could be remedied by a drain from the well to the river.

The girls are taught to milk and during the spring and summer do considerable work in the garden.

The boiler room is well arranged and all machinery is in splendid condition. The mechanic is a first class man and thoroughly understands his work.

The barns and outbuildings are in good repair and the yards tidy. At present the milk supply is low, but a number of cows will freshen within the next few weeks. The stock is all well cared for and in fair flesh.

Poultry is kept and a fair success made. The eggs are used for the children and staff.

The dispensary is one of the neatest and best arranged I have inspected. All drugs are well looked after and kept locked to avoid any accident.

The Reverend Father Carrier appears to be a good manager and is ably assisted by a well qualified staff.

I have the honour to be,

Sir:-

Reverend Father Carriere, Principal of the Cowessess Residential School, came in to see me recently and informed me that the laundry floor in the school became in such poor condition, owing to the presence of a cess-pool underneath it that he had to take immediate steps to have it repaired.

It appears that there was a well or cess-pool under the laundry which was pumped out daily. The Public Health Officer condemned this cess-pool and ordered it to be filled up, as it was liable to contaminate the water supply. I understand that owing to its presence the sewage backed up, smelt bad, and was a menace to the health of the children. The Reverend Father has had the floor repaired, the well filled up, and has installed a drainage system at a cost of $51.00, and has asked me if I will present the matter to the Department with a view to receiving a refund of the amount he has expended. August 9th, 1933

Sir:

When visiting the Cowessess Indian Residential School yesterday to examine the boiler which has been giving trouble I casually enquired of the Revd. Fr. Chatelaine, acting principal, whether the inspection and steam boiler license was up to date. He was not familiar with the circumstances and the engineer Pierre Kernton who has been at the school for many years has resigned.

As a consequence of my enquiry I was permitted by Fr. Chatelaine to go through the school files to see what the present standing of the boiler license and inspection would be as far as possible. I found very little information but found Department letter 108-2-5 dated July 21st, 1931 to which was attached the enclosed account. Apparently Fr. Carriere failed to certify and return this account to the Department as instructed and nothing further was done.

As the steam boiler in question is in very bad condition and possibly should be condemned entirely I am asking the steam boiler inspector to visit the school and examine the boiler but in doing so there is a possibility that the question of inspecting and licensing this boiler may be raised and as far as I am able to determine at the present time the school have been very negligent in this connection. There may be some information in the hands of the Department of which I am not aware as Fr. Carriere's filing system was not good. I am informed by one of the members of the school staff that the boiler inspector was at the school last year but did not examine the boiler, while Fr. Carrier in conversation at one time informed me that the boiler had been examined and could not be repaired.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs

Sir:

In this connection I have to say that the Department paid an account of $30.00 for the inspection of the H. R. T. I have had the Boiler Inspector examine this boiler and he reports that it "is O.K. for 100 lbs of steam" making it suitable for the school purposes.

Sir:

I have to report that whilst at the Cowessess Indian Residential School on Friday the 13th inst., a fire broke out about noon in the floor of a small granary adjoining the large implement shed. Before the same was discovered the fire had jumped from the granary to the implement shed and both were burning freely before we commenced using the fire extinguishers on the fire.

The flame was mounting fully ten feet high but with the use of five 2½ gallon Nomite Extinguishers the fire was soon under control and within half an hour was completely extinguished. One end of the Implement Shed was badly burned and the floor of the small granary was considerably damaged.

The Department will not be asked to pay for any repairs in this connection. There is no doubt that only the prompt use of very efficient extinguishers saved a great loss of property.

On investigating the cause of the fire there seems to be no doubt that it originated from the burning of grass in the Indian Cemetery which forms part of the school grounds. This grass was burned early in the morning before my arrival at the school and there was no sign of fire when we went to the basement for lunch at 12 O'clock but I am sure that some sparks from the burning grass had blown under the granary (which was on 8" skids) where it had smouldered in some long grass and eventually been fanned into a flame by the high wind which was then blowing. The Lay Brother who was in charge of the work stated that there was no fire in sight when he went to lunch, nevertheless I feel there is no doubt that some sparks blew under the granary unknown to him.

Having seen the good work which these extinguishers perform I would suggest that at least one should be placed in each dwelling.
dwelling
of this Agency as I am sure that the Agent's residence which
burned here a year ago could have been saved by proper use of
2 Fosmite Extinguishers.

I have instructed the Revd. Principal to have his empty
extinguishers immediately refilled as we emptied practically all
the good ones in the school and there was no time to wait for
Departmental Authority to have them refilled.

I trust my action will be approved.

Your obedient servant,

J. P. B. Ostrander

Sir:

I beg to inform the Department that I have had a complaint from the Reverend Principal of the Cowessess Indian Residential School in the Crooked Lakes Agency to the effect that their low pressure boiler which is used for heating purposes is completely worn out.

This boiler was installed thirty years ago. It was manufactured by the Brandon Machine Works who are now not in business. I have today had an interview with Mr. George Drayser, Steam boiler Inspector for the Department of Labour, Hallways, etc., Saskatchewan. He informs me that he has examined this boiler thoroughly and it is his opinion that it would be a waste of money to attempt to repair it. It requires eighty 3" flues, 12 feet long, and in the Inspector's opinion the shell of the boiler is so badly eaten that it would be a waste of money to refuel it. At the present time they are using a high pressure threshing engine boiler, but this boiler has not sufficient capacity to heat the building during cold weather. The engineer has to be constantly on hand in the boiler room while it is being operated.

The Principal is very anxious to get his heating unit in proper shape at the earliest possible date, as the cold weather may start in at any time now. I have consulted Messrs. Potts and Miller, Plumbers of this City, with regard to the price of a suitable heating boiler and they quote a price of $1,620.00 F.O.B. Broadview for an Inglis boiler made in Toronto, 7700 feet radiator capacity. Added to this would be the cost of transporting the boiler about twenty miles from Broadview - to the school and -

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
to the school and installing it. Messrs. Potts and Miller state that the outside cost they estimate would be about $2,500.00, but it might be done for less.

I have also received a proposition from the Regina Brewing Company who have a Leonard Two Pass Steel boiler which has only been operated for about three months. This boiler has a radiator capacity of about 15,000 feet. I am told that the original cost of the boiler was about $4,500.00. They offer it to us for $1,000.00 on car at Regina. Mr. Draayer, the Boiler Inspector, tells me that the boiler is as good as new and would heat a much larger building than the school in question. Added to their offer would be transportation from Regina to the school and the installation as well, which would be about the same as the cost of installing the low pressure boiler.

I shall be glad to have the Department give this matter consideration and advise me of the action it is proposed will be taken.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I beg to report that I visited the Cowessess Indian Residential School at Crooked Lakes yesterday afternoon for the purpose of inspecting their heating system which is not working satisfactorily and is not heating the building during the cold weather.

I found that during the recent cold snap the pipes had burst in their store rooms, as well as their hot water heating tank, and it is imperative that repairs be made at once in order that the school building may be properly heated.

As previously reported, the low pressure boiler which has been in operation for over thirty years was condemned by the boiler inspector and is not in use. They have been endeavoring to heat the building with a high pressure steam threshing boiler, which is installed for the purpose of generating power to run their laundry equipment, etc. The boiler at times has a pressure of 80 pounds of steam and in order to utilize it for heating purposes, it has been found necessary to get a reducing valve between the boiler and the radiation system to allow not more than a maximum of 15 pounds of steam to enter the radiation system. It has been found impossible to operate this boiler with sufficient steam to heat the building, in as much as the condensed steam returning to the boiler from the radiation system is at a much lower pressure than the pressure in the boiler. It is therefore necessary to at once install either a steam pump to force the return into the boiler, or have the return discharged into an open tank and injected from there into the boiler, in order to keep the system operating.

H. W. McGill, Esq., M.D.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
I have today taken the matter up with heating engineers here and they are of the opinion that by installing a trap to prevent the live steam from returning to the open tank and allowing the condensed steam only to return and by providing an additional injector to keep up the water supply in the boiler, the system can be made to function although it will require more or less constant attention.

The Reverend Principal has obtained a reducing valve at a cost of $25.00. The cost of the trap, injector, necessary pipe, and valves to complete the system including a new hot water tank is estimated at the outside to cost not more than $150.00. If a steam pump had to be installed, it would cost twice that amount to put the system in proper shape to heat the building. This is a Government owned school. As it is imperative that the repairs be made at once in order to render the school habitable, I have asked the Reverend Principal if he will take care of the expense should there be no funds available. The Engineer from the school is coming in this afternoon and we will decide exactly what will be necessary in order to put the boiler in working order. I would be glad to have your authority to issue vouchers covering this expenditure. It is an emergency which was not anticipated until the real cold weather arrived and it was found that the high pressure boiler without the aforementioned attachment could not be utilized to heat the building properly.

Yours very truly,

W. Murison,
Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

The low pressure boiler, used in heating the main building of the Cowessess Indian Residential School (Cowessess Reserve, No. 73, Crooked Lake Agency, Federal District of Melville), Sask., is completely worn out. This boiler was installed 30 years ago. Mr. Inspector Murison, Regina, had a Steam Boiler Inspector for the Department of Labour, Railways, etc., Saskatchewan, examine the boiler, and it is the opinion of the Inspector that it would be a waste of money to attempt to repair it. This boiler gave out last winter, and the building was heated with a high pressure threshing boiler, which was unsatisfactory, as the building was not properly heated.

Mr. Inspector Murison obtained, from Messrs. Potts & Miller, Limited, Regina, a quotation of $1,620, f. o. b. Broadview, Sask., for an Inglis boiler, 7700 ft. radiator capacity. The boiler would have to be hauled a distance of about 20 miles from Broadview to the school and there would be labour in connection with its installation. The outside estimate of the cost would be about $2,500, and it might be done for less.

This is a government-owned school. No funds have been specially provided in our appropriation for Indian Education to cover the cost of supplying and installing a new boiler. However, we have an item of $8,000 in the Estimates, for unforeseen expenditure. The cost involved in the supplying and installing of a new boiler could be taken from this amount. Mr. Inspector Murison states it is urgent that adequate heating facilities at this school be installed before next winter.

I beg to submit, for your consideration and approval, the granting of authority for the expenditure required and the purchase and installation of the boiler from Messrs. Potts & Miller, Limited, Regina.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

A request has been received, through the authorities of the Oblate Order, under whose auspices the Cowessess Indian Residential School is conducted, that certain decorating be carried out in the interior of the building. They request that paint be supplied for the walls and ceiling of two dormitories, varnish for upstairs and downstairs halls and also paint for seven staff rooms and pharmacy. It is requested, further, that the plaster be renewed on the walls only of the boys' playroom; that burlap be installed around the base, 5 ft. in height; that 300 ft. of V joint fir be supplied for a partition in the parlour; and that the chimneys of the school be cleaned.

For your information, I may say that our Estimates include the sum of $750 for interior painting in the main school building and for miscellaneous repairs, also the sum of $250 to purchase new batteries for the electric light plant.

I would request that you arrange, after consulting the Principal regarding the material required, for the purchase of the quantity of paint, varnish, V joint fir and burlap. You should make purchase from firms on the approved list. The Department will approve, also, of an expenditure in cleaning the chimneys of the school and for the labour in renewing the plaster in the boys' playroom and installing burlap. It is understood that the school authorities will be responsible for all labour in the painting and varnishing and installing partition in parlour. It will be necessary to obtain the services of a plasterer to do the work required in the boys' playroom. The estimate submitted by the Principal, covering the cost of the above improvements, is $350, in addition to the labour that can be carried out by the school authorities, themselves.

Itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified by you, should be forwarded, covering the cost of materials and for the outside labour. Regarding the labour, the number of days or hours employed and the rate paid should be definitely stated. The entire cost should be kept as close as possible to the estimate mentioned above.

Please advise if new batteries for the lighting system will be required, and, if so, you should state definitely the type and size.

Yours truly,

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I have Mr. Pratt's memorandum of the 5th instant, relative to providing a grant of $2,500 to assist in the rebuilding of a barn at the Coosaeese Indian Residential School, on the Crooked Lake Reserve.

Requests for the erection of a new barn have been made by the Principal and the Church Authorities during the past few years, but, owing to the many demands for repairs and equipment at the various schools, it was not found possible to provide the funds to erect a barn. The new barn is required for cattle, as they keep a large herd at this school. The present facilities are inadequate, and there is no doubt that a new barn is required.

No funds are provided in the Appropriation for the current fiscal year to cover the cost of erecting a new barn. When preparing our Estimates for the coming fiscal year, consideration could be given to including an item to cover the amount required for this purpose. I am today in receipt of a letter from Father Chatelain stating that these improvements have been made and that the total amount spent was $409.01; all the labor in connection with the work was paid for by the Principal. The kitchen range is completely worn; would it not be possible to supply the School with a new range out of the 1936 Vote. A few cupboards should be provided for the classrooms also, and three doors leading to the fire escapes in the dormitories. As far as the cupboards and doors are concerned you may supply materials only as the Principal will pay all labor.

The Marieval School has received very little these last several years in the way of interior improvements, and I hope that you will comply with the Principal's request in this particular case.

Reverend Sir:

Sir,

I beg to advise that a new boiler was installed for the furnace at the Cowessess Indian Residential School, in Aug. 1935, at that time those installing it although they advised it, claimed that their contract did not cover the placing asbestos around the main heat from the furnace to the building. The pipe was left bare and while the Principal of the school at that time stated that his engineer could do this work and would do it if the Department would supply the necessary material, the necessary authority was not obtained at that time. For Paste asbestos the estimated cost to cover a 5 in. pipe 70 feet in length was $75.

During the recent cold spell the Principal had fruit jars broken from frost and vegetables frozen to the approximate value of $90 due to the fact that a great deal of the heat is lost in coming from the furnace to the main building, a distance of almost 70 feet, through this bare pipe.

The Principal thinks that the cost of $75, formerly estimated for paste asbestos could be reduced somewhat by the use of asbestos paper covering held tight by brass binding. The school staff could do the work in connection therewith if the Department would furnish the material.

In the face of your recent letter regarding this school the Principal feels loath to bring this to your attention but also feels that with cold weather, this condition will be aggravated throughout the winter.

Can anything be done to repair this defect in installation of the furnace and pipe?

Your obedient servant,

Eben A.W.R. McKenzie,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to advise that there are certain repairs that the Principal of the Cowessess School asks for, labor for which can be carried out by the school staff during the summer holidays if the Department supplies the material and replacements. These are as undernoted:

Generator for the light plant, 32 Volt, has given out. Principal can make replacement on one he has tried and found satisfactory for difference of $40.00

Pressure tanks at school so connected that pressure is being secured from only one tank resulting in having to pump for pressure four to five times daily. These require to be properly connected at top and bottom with proper intake and outlet pipes whereby pressure would come from the three rather than one and pressure could be maintained by one pumping per day. As it is at present there is very little if any pressure during night; changing of pipes, elbows &c. connecting three and also pipe line can be done for material at an estimated cost of $50.00

Lime for plaster, lumber and nails to complete a refractory in the basement for Principal and Vice-Principal's use. Material to cost $50.00

In laundry room, a stove pipe runs from the clothes boiler up through a floor into room above and enters the chimney there. As there is a great heat from this pipe the principal proposes building a chimney starting from bracket in the laundry room, he has almost sufficient bricks for this purpose and estimates that he can complete with additional material costing $12.00

May I have authority to purchase the material asked for by the Principal, please?

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Following up complaints from the Reverend Principal of the Cowessess Indian Residential School regarding the sewage disposal system, I beg to advise that one of the engineers of the Department of Public Health inspected the system and reports as follows:

Apparently defects in the plumbing system have existed for some time and I am informed that the trap on one of the bath-tub wastes, on the second floor, syphons when the water closet alongside is flushed which permits a strong odour to permeate the building. Also the sewage at times backs up into the laundry although the laundry floor is about 18 inches above the rest of the basement. Very strong and obnoxious odours result whenever the sewage backs up.

It appears to me that the reason for the syphoning of the bathtub trap is due to improper venting or else some blockage has occurred since installation was made. The backing up of the laundry sewer appears to be due to blockage in the drain at some point between the laundry and the septic tank as there is no complaint of other fixtures on this drain giving trouble. It is probable that the blockage is between the laundry room and the first clean out. It is possible that the backing up of the sewage is due to a clogging of the outfall pipe from the septic tank although in this case, all drains would be expected to back up.

There are three main drains from the building to the septic tank. It is probable that there are no basement connections to the other two drains so that a backing up would not be noticed.

In order to adjust the difficulty it will be necessary for a plumber to check up on the installation, especially the venting at the units where syphonage takes place and probably rodding the various drains to remove any blockage which may have taken place.

Sgd J.G.Schaeffer B.Sc.
Sanitary Engineer.

May I have authority to have a plumber look over this school and remedy the defects in the sewage system as at present in order to prevent backing up they have to pump out the sludge well about every two weeks.
