Extract from letter dated July 6, 1938, received from Dr. J. J. WALL.

It is with respect to the fire hazard at night in four of our Schools. They are Sandy Bay, Man., Round Lake and Cowessess of Broadview, Sask., and lastly and especially Hobbema, Alta. In any of these institutions, should I sleep there, I always have the flash-light, overcoat, socks and gloves available and prepared for a sudden dive into the winter night. This fear in these four places certainly has not become an obsession but it has started to bother my conscience.

I know how foolish it would be in these hard times to imagine that funds are available for proper reconstruction. But is it not possible to get proper escape apparatus installed. Every second for evacuation time must be conserved. I am not frightened so much of the flames at night but I am fearful of the superheated gases developing and flooding the halls. Only a partial lung-ful of this and a person is out. All the fire fighting equipment possible will not avail such a case. That was my experience years ago at the Royal Victoria in Montreal when we had that terrible movie fire which took so many children. It was not the flames, as I recollect, none were even scorched.

My belief is that this problem can be solved in preparing proper escapes. Iced poles of iron, narrow snow or ice filled metal stairs on the outside possibly open to a wall of flames from some window it passes will only add to the panic at night. Poor lighting over these meager affairs will not assist.

The panic in the children when a real fire does break will be stupendous. The stoical Indian in such case is a figment on the part of certain popular authors.

Don't be sore at me, Phil., as I am prepared to lay a two to one bet up to $100 bucks that in case of such an eventuality in any of the four, happening in winter between ten at night and four in the morning, the mortality will exceed...
thirty per cent.

The ideal thing would be an inspection of each by an officer, like the Chief of the Montreal brigade, who has had plenty of experience dealing with such institutional hazards. His first consideration would be to figure the route the fire and gases would take so that adequate methods and routes of escape can be instituted. Steel fire doors would undoubtedly be installed on each floor above the first. Steel tower-like escapes as on the Kent Street School at Ottawa would replace at strategic points the old dangerous poles and narrow stairs. Lists of pupils to utilize each escape would be posted at all times and each child's name checked from list as it passes by a responsible guardian. Many of the children otherwise, in the event of a genuine alarm will, if not watched, take refuge in a clothes closet or under its bed.

Night watchman was a step in the right direction but much can happen in the winter when he is punching in the outbuildings and barn and the time he returns to the school.

Much as I hate to bring your attention to this whole question in these four places, please understand it is not done so with any sense of butting in. It is for these poor kiddies sake, many of whom one becomes attached in his duties. In case also, should any catastrophe arise, we all shall be scourged properly at any investigation especially at the hands of politically conscious lawyers who cynically will give little credit to those who really and truly have the fullest interests of these tots at heart.
EX'D.

In official letter of May 13 last you were advised that in preparing our appropriation for the current fiscal year it was found possible to include an item of $360.00 only for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at the Cowessess School. When the account for the dough mixer was paid there was only a balance of approximately $50.00.

Since that time we have authorized $420.60 for repairs to the sewage system. Recently we received an account of $55.55 for general repairs and a cheque for this will go forward in the near future. You will note from the above that the Department has expended considerably more at this school during the current academic year than was originally intended. Under these circumstances it is not possible to favourably consider purchasing the desks and generator at the present time.

Yours truly,

Mr. Ebem A.W.R. McKenzie,
Indian Agent
Broadview, Sask.

Dear Sir:

Since two months, we have encountered many difficulties with our Power-Plant. As it were emergency cases, I have requested the services of an expert electrician, Mr. Arthur Kendrick. His visits and his days work amount to £31.70 which I beg the Department to pay. And still, we are in danger of being without light at any moment. The one cylinder Lister engine is nearly gone, after 18 years of service. Rev. Fr. Chatelain had it overhauled last summer, and is still in a bad shape; the 2 pumps-magneto and bearings are wore out. The batteries bought by you 3 years ago are gone also, the plates are warping, and Mr. Kendrick says: they will soon, after the heavy drain they receive every day, be gone also. Consequently, I urge the necessity of a complete new plant of 110 volts diesel Lister which will be able to stand the consumption we need in our institution, caused mostly to the long cable runs.

Furthermore, may I ask another favor of having our outside buildings repainted next spring; it will be at the honor of the Department to see these buildings with a better looking. Especially, the calves shed is a disgrace in the yard. Also the cow barn would require some urgent repair.

We have fixed already the fowl-house, so much so, that we collect every day 90 eggs, well appreciated by the children.

We are in the present time, repairing and repainting the inside of the laundry, you will not recognize it. Soon, the furnace room will have its cleaning and whitewashing.

Yours truly,

Rev. V. de Varennes
Principal

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 13th instant with reference to the lighting plant at the Cowessess Indian residential school. You may forward a voucher covering the cost of the repairs to this plant.

Owing to lack of funds it is not possible at the present time to consider the purchase of a new lighting plant for this school. However, in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1939-40 provision has been made for funds for improvements and purchase of new equipment at this school. If the lighting plant is considered the most necessary item the Department is prepared to consider its purchase after the first of April. In that event you should let me have full particulars regarding the equipment required in order that the purchase may be handled by our Purchasing Branch.

In the event of the Lister lighting plant being purchased it should be distinctly understood by the Principal that its cost will absorb all the funds provided for the Cowessess residential school in our appropriation for 1939-40 and under these circumstances it will not be possible to consider any other improvements at that school during the next fiscal year.

Yours truly,

E.A.W.R. McKenzie, Esq.,

Ottawa, March 11, 1939.

Reverend Sir:

I enclose account which has just been received from Simmons Limited, Winnipeg, covering the cost of beds, springs, mattresses and pillows, supplied to the Cowessess Residential School.

Some months ago we received a similar account and cheque in payment was issued during the month of January, 1939. When the Simmons Company wrote us about the matter we so advised them and in reply they stated that they made two shipments on October 3 for the same amount.

As stated above, we have paid the first account, but as we are nearing the end of the fiscal year our funds are completely assigned, and it is not possible to consider payment of the attached account. If the school received two shipments, as stated by the company, it will be necessary for you to pay the enclosed account from school funds.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

"I consider for the moment the purchase of a new Electric Plant the most necessary item. Sir:-

Acknowledging receipt of your letter 108-2-5 of the 20th, instant, regarding electric light plant at the Cowessess School, I beg to enclose herewith a letter from the Principal of this school together with a diagram of the buildings down there. I am also enclosing a letter received by the Principal from Mumford, Redland, Ltd., concerning a direct generator and an engine that they have.

There are 117 lighting outlets at present, none further anticipated; the voltage of lamps 110; no motors at present but one anticipated for the use of the bread-mixer, which would use 2100 watts, but would only be on at the time of making bread. There are no electrical appliances.

I trust that this is the detail you require.

Your obedient servant,
